As a devout fan of grand strategy games, I often find myself searching for titles that offer both depth and accessibility. In this quest, I stumbled upon Age of History II here on Steam, and I must say, it has exceeded all my expectations.

From the moment I launched the game, I was greeted with a vast array of options and possibilities. With several different historical scenarios spanning from antiquity to the modern era, the sheer scope of Age of History is staggering. Whether you want to rewrite the events of World War II, lead ancient civilizations to glory, or craft your own alternate history, the game provides the tools and flexibility to do so.

One of the most commendable aspects of Age of History II is its attention to detail. Each scenario is meticulously researched and crafted, capturing the nuances of historical events, cultures, and conflicts. Whether you're commanding legions of Roman soldiers, orchestrating diplomatic maneuvers in the Renaissance, or navigating the complexities of modern geopolitics, every decision feels consequential and immersive.

The gameplay mechanics of this game strike a delicate balance between complexity and accessibility. While the game offers a staggering depth of strategic options, including diplomacy, warfare, trade, and espionage, it also provides intuitive controls and user-friendly interfaces that make it easy for newcomers to jump in and start playing. Whether you're a seasoned strategist or a newcomer to the genre, *Age of History II* offers a rewarding and engaging experience for players of all skill levels.

Furthermore, the game's vibrant modding community adds an extra layer of longevity and replayability. With a wealth of user-created content ranging from new scenarios and historical events to gameplay tweaks and graphical enhancements, there's always something new to discover in Age of History. Whether you want to explore new historical eras, delve into alternate history scenarios, or simply customize your gaming experience to suit your preferences, the possibilities are endless.

In conclusion, Age of History II stands as a shining example of the grand strategy genre. With its vast array of historical scenarios, attention to detail, and engaging gameplay mechanics, it offers an immersive and rewarding experience that will keep you coming back for more. Whether you're a history buff, a strategy enthusiast, or simply looking for a compelling gaming experience, this game is an absolute must-have for your Steam library.

The $5 you'll spend on this will buy you enough playtime to at least make it worth the money. 

There's a lot of content with minimal depth, and so it feels you're simply paying for an experience on figuring out a new strategy game. It's something I enjoyed, but that can also be a downside if mechanical depth is more your interest; due to the number of variables you have control over.

The AI is super simple, and obviously cheats to make up for that fact. The AI also has murderous tendencies where I've had seven different countries declare war on me without any reasonable proximity, all at once. Once these wars are going, there's a reasonable chance that the AI can and will keep throwing troops at you with no chance of winning, and no chance of surrendering to spite that.

It's also a very buggy game with sometimes game breaking bugs, and minor nuisances bugs feeling very common.

I wouldn't recommend this to be a go-to strategy game of choice.
This is more of a starter strategy game, or side-game if your game of choice is losing its luster.

However, it's definitely worth the money for the time you can get out of it.

The game is rather quite fun, and it's kind of a more casual version of the Paradox games.
The recent name change though, oh good lord. It doesn't do the game good, as it's about countries, and is not about following history. It's like calling a Fort a Field, A fort is well defended and commonly hard to breach, A field otherwise, is wide open to walk through. The original name "Age of Civilizations II" is much better of a representation, and does it good.
Still, please play this game if you enjoy this Genre.

Edit:
This game has not aged the best, lets establish that. This game is still fine but has not been updated in years, and still has a surprising amount of bugs. I'm not going to say you shouldn't try this game, but before you do please accommodate your mindset to it having aged without much maintenence.

One of my top 10 games of all time. Not for graphics or story or mechanics. But for the replayability and freedom to do pretty much whatever you desire. I made Czechoslovakia in the modern day, and then took all of Eastern Europe, The Middle East and about a third of Asia. Not once did I get bored, because when I wanted a quick break I could tell a few countries to go to war and watch the absolute chaos. You could make the Maori the first African colonisers if you wanted. You could take all of Europe with a one province nation with no economy or port, surrounded on all sides by a globe-spanning Empire. The possibilities are endless.

Age of History 2 is a great game to get into the genre. This game is a strategic in-between to the extremes of Paradox games like HoI4 and the board game RISK. It's also a game with many customization options that are easily accessible. For example, if you have an issue with a formable nation requiring too much land, there's a way to change it. You can also make your own start dates, your own countries, your own leaders, etc. As a single player experience, it is absolutely incredible that one individual made this game by himself. While, yes, this is a mobile game port, it's a REALLY GOOD mobile game. It deserved being put on PC just as much as Polytopia.

Unfortunately, multiplayer is heavily lacking. The only way to play with multiple people is with a "Pass and Play" system, which works on mobile fine I guess, but for PC it's terrible. There's also no Steam Workshop, meaning that if you want to use things created by other people, it requires a lot of effort and troubleshooting to get right. That certainly applies to making maps for the game as well. It's possible, but requires an external program, a lot of trial and error, and knowing what files need to be edited. The game would benefit heavily from having a map creator built-in, but that is unlikely to happen anytime soon.

The biggest issue, though, is how buggy this game is. It certainly takes some getting used to, but while most can be avoided when you get the hang of things, some will pop up every time you play the game. I don't blame the developer, who has likely put as much time in the game as he wanted to and wishes to move on, but it'd be nice to see this stuff fixed. If relations with other nations reset to 0 after turn 1000, or the names go completely bonkers, or the screen starts randomly flashing, you're simply just gonna have to deal with it for now. If you don't buy it because it's buggy, I can't blame you.

HOWEVER, if you are thinking about buying this game, I think you absolutely should. It isn't a perfect game, but if you only care about single player, this game is worth more than its price point would even indicate. Those flaws are very outweighed by the game's positives. You buy this game to create scenarios with little effort compared to many other games. You buy this game to create an empire without having to learn thousands of in-game systems. You buy this game to do WHATEVER you want to do. This game will fall out of many's favor as they begin to prefer other more complicated, less buggy games, but personally I think this is a grand first step into playing strategy map games.

UPDATE: Since AoH3 is releasing sometime in the future, many may wonder whether it's still worth buying this game. Everything above still applies, and I honestly think this will still be a good first step strategy game after RISK. AoH3 is moving into real-time instead of a turn-based system, is likely adding generals, army compositions, techs, laws and reforms, more provinces, and god knows how much else. If AoH3 delivers on everything, I'd recommend it as a step 2 more than likely. Also, the original Age of History is bad. Do not even bother trying to find it.

If this isn't the most simple strategy game that's fun playing, then I don't know what game it is. If you've played Hearts of Iron IV, then you'll be shocked how simple this game is compared to Hoi4. Overall the game is so simple yet so enjoyable, to this day I'm still playing it, as it's my favorite strategy game. And it's only 5 euros, if you have 5 euros in your steam wallet, and you like history, and strategy games, I would definitely recommend you this game, it takes minutes or maximum 2 hours to learn how the game works. If you have a bad pc or a laptop, i think it could run this game, so it's really great. Overall it's the most simple, and enjoyable strategy game for me. I would really recommend it. Can't wait for Age of History 3 to come out.

[h1] Age of History II Review [/h1]

Age of History II is an immersive strategy game that allows players to rewrite history. With a vast selection of countries and scenarios to choose from, but offers a bad gaming experience. Whether you go diplomacy, warfare, or economic strategy, this game anyway make you go on war with everyone.

There no attention to historical detail. History going by his way, it's adds a layer of intrigue to each playthrough. The gameplay may be intimidating at first, but by time you will understand all tricks of the game.

Overall, Age of History II is a horrible for fans of strategy games and history gamers. But anyway this game can interest by his easy gameplay, whether you're commanding mighty empires or a city.
great

So I've been playing this for a long time, playing it on mobile and PC. I only have about 200 hours on steam but I've technically played for much longer. Here's an honest review:

Pros:
- Easy to learn
- Highly Customizable
- Built-in Scenario Editor
- Can run it easily even on a potato PC
- Turn based gameplay
- A Europe, World, and Asia map
- Easy to Modify files

Cons:
- Minor/Less Game breaking bugs
- Major/Game Breaking bugs
- Zero game fixing updates
- Pretty bad AI
- Turns at times take long

There are many bugs, but there's only 4 (that I've found) that are Game breaking.

1. The UI disappears, and the map starts flashing (I've sometimes fixed this by pressing Esc.)

2. Save games don't work (I've fixed this by loading other working save games)

3. Turns freeze (I have no clue how to fix this)

4. Game crashes when you load a save game (Happens when a save game is bugged, usually fixed by going into the games files and removing the latest one.)

Overall, I really enjoy the game, and would recommend it if you can deal with the bugs. It's easy to learn, but hard to master. I also recommend that you play with mods, since they make the game experience much better. However, since Lucas never fulfilled his promises, there's no workshop. However, there is a forums page where you can install mods. So overall, pretty good game I guess. 7.5/10

Age of History 2 seems like a game that could have been fantastic, but it's fallen into a pit of abandonment. The developer seems to have vanished into thin air since 2020, leaving this potentially great game in a state of neglect.

Let's start with the AI, it's beyond infuriating. The in-game artificial intelligence is as dumb as a sack of bricks. They engage in wars that make no sense, wars they can't possibly win, and refuse to surrender even when you've occupied 80% of their territory and just want a couple of provinces. It's like dealing with an army following orders of "no step back," reminiscent of the Soviets or the futile defense of the Reichstag by the Germans.

And don't even get me started on the technical issues. The game is riddled with bugs and crashes. The forced autosaves, which you can't even turn off, cause constant disruptions, leading to frequent crashes. Sometimes, the game decides to fling you across the map for no apparent reason, making it more of a frustrating experience than an enjoyable one.

The sheer annoyance caused by these technical problems has reached a breaking point for me. It's disheartening to see a potentially great game ruined by the negligence of the developers. The lack of support, combined with the numerous bugs and the infuriating AI, has soured my experience to the point where I no longer have any desire to continue playing.

I really tried to like this game. Despite so many frustrations and wonky games I kept pushing forward. The only thing this has brought me was rage. 

The A.I need serious improvement . I could occupy an entire country, want a single province, yet they still refuse peace with me. I could be at war with someone across the map for 100 turns, because they refuse peace despite us not having fought a single battle. The AI will also have very little army in most tiles. Then have 7500 Troops in a random tile. They spread out like a cancer if they make a single breakthrough with the 7 thousand troops they randomly have in one tile. 

Next, I hate how I will randomly be directing my troops, then for some reason the game flings me over half way across the map. I don't think its a problem on my end because I have never experienced this before. 

finally, the tutorial is confusing and unhelpful. On top of that, I still dont know how to stop my troops from moving someplace. Once they are set it wont let me move them away or someplace else. I say this because the tutorial didnt bother to teach me IF it is even a feature. 

Overall, not worth it has only pissed me off.

It has recently been announced that Age of History 3 is in the making. I am excited, and maybe Lukasz can redeem himself by making this one an absolute gem. As they say, third times the charm! The prices you've applied to Turkey seem like a joke. As a country, we didn't switch to the dollar; Steam switched to the dollar to keep prices stable in Turkey and prevent constant fluctuations. What you should have done was convert the price you applied to us into dollars. In other words, the price would have remained the same, and we would have purchased it in dollars. [h2]A few words about the game[/h2]
If you are looking for cheap and simple strategy game and you always wanted to play some games like this one but they were too hard for you - this is where you should start. Yet, this game is not even close to being perfect strategy game.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Advantages[/h2]
- Game is really simple. You can learn every mechanic in less than 2 hours of playing.
- In my opinion this is best looking game of this kind. Simple and realistic. You can really feel like strategist over a war map.
- Description of the game is lying. This game is really easy to master...
- ...and that makes it perfect as entrance to the world of strategic games!
- Game has a lot of scenarios, maps and settings so you can make it easier/harder.
- You can spend a lot of time in the game. 
- You can recreate Roman Empire and get achievement for forming Australia-Hungary XD
- Cheap
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Disadvantages[/h2]
- Game is simple and easy to master so you will have no challanges.
- A lot of bugs. Your army can sometimes disappear or after too much time on the save the diplomatic relations are broken.
- No updates 
- No realism in the game. Unrealistic economy, diplomacy, amounts of units. Head of the country can live like 300 years.
- There is multiplayer in the game but it's really bad. The mechanics of the game make multiplayer gameplay really slow.
- Music and audio isn't really good. You can hear the main theme in a lot of youtube videos. 
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Rating[/h2]
Graphics: 7/10
Gameplay: 5.5/10
Audio: 3/10
Price: 9/10
[b]Overall: 6/10[/b]
its a good game if you are good at learning and avoiding bugs. do not buy if you expect a polished product.

The game is just a numbers game with a lot of flaws. Very little strategy if any (basically the country with higher numbers wins), AI is dog-water and just declares war/makes peace seemingly at random, and diplomacy is bare-bones and easily exploitable, just to name a few flaws. Also, for one reason or another, the dev went completely dark and the game hasn't had a proper (as in any update that isn't just a new pointless scenario) update in around 4-5 years, so what you get now is pretty much what it's always going to be. Its a shame too, because I think if this game got some polishing and actual content updates, it PROBABLY could've been a really fun game. The only reason I still play it from time to time is that it's a kinda decent time waster, but even as a time waster the bugs can be really annoying and even game breaking. If you're looking for a well designed 4X grand strategy game that can rival HOI4 or EU4, this definitely is not it. But I guess if you're looking for a half-baked mobile game to pass the time, then maybe this is the game for you?

You flex your finger muscles ‚Äì a simple click ‚Äì and suddenly, the world is awash with a kaleidoscope of colors. This is the zenith of strategic gaming, the very essence of pure, unadulterated brilliance.

The cold hard cash, enters the scene. This is the golden ticket to keep those colors flowing, to keep the dream alive. And then, the pi√®ce de r√©sistance: you can mod this game. You can tinker and toy with it until the colors dance to your tune. It is a mesmerizing, technicolor symphony, and I am head over heels for it.

If you are seeking the epitome of simplicity seasoned with a dash of financial finesse and a pinch of modder's magic, look no further. This game is your ticket to a world where clicking, color changing, and customization reign supreme.

[b][u]xVeli's reviews - Age Of History[/u][/b]


[h1] Description [/h1]

[b]Age of History II[/b] is an indie game created by ≈Åukasz Jakowski about trying to conquer the world as a country of your choice. I got acquainted with this game in 2020, and until now I play it from time to time with long breaks. There's not much to say about this game, except that you can play many scenarios (e.g. 1440s, Napoleonic Wars, World War I or World War II, or Modern Day), create your own, edit countries, gain the entire world and achievements... and basically that's it. 

The huge downside of this game, which in my opinion ruins most of the fun of the gameplay, is the AI of other countries - it is terrible. Imagine that you play such Sweden and suddenly out of your ass such Congo sends you a diplomatic insult, and such Kazakhstan declares war on you. Kazakhstan, declaring war on Sweden. The worst is when, as a result of a war between other countries, the borders are changed to heavily chaotic and unrealistic (so-called bordergore). Oh, and there's also the situation when the state you're at war with has territories inside another state with which you don't have good relations. Because of this, that state blocks you from gaining a province, through which you can't end the war.

Other than that, the game is great and there is a lot of fun with it. I recommend playing it when you are bored.

[b]PC Requirements: Small .[/b]

I'm not hating on Kevin MacLeod, cause he's a legend for making all of his songs free. It's just the soundtrack consists of literally 15 nonoriginal songs. And it loops. So after having a playing session for 3 hours it becomes so painful that I need to mute the music and use my spotify / some YT essays.

They are not that bad, but not the best either.

The game is VERY easy to learn and a little bit hard to master. It's very simplistic.

[b]Game Time: INFINITE + Fan content: 2/10[/b]
You can play as long as you want, so it's infinite ig. Also there is almost none fan content (mapping is NOT a fan content of GAMES).

[b]Price: 8.5/10[/b]
Fair price, could be a little cheaper.

[b]Overall: 6/10[/b]

Okay, I just have to start out by admitting that I left a positive review of this game when I first played it. However, I was much younger back then and had yet to play truly great grand strategy games such as Victoria 2 or Crusader Kings. Now, in hidnsight, as much as I did have some amount of enjoyment playing it as a kid/young teen, I must admit this this game is honestly...bad.

The graphics are a no-brainer. They look awful. The world map is actually the color of vomit unless you either cover every square inch of the planet with country land (which reminds me of something I'll get back to later) or download a mod to make the graphics better, hopefully also one which fixes the disgustingly bad province borders and lack of content in this game.

The mechanics are dull, repetitive, and buggy as hell. To take out a loan, all you need to have is a certain number of arbitrary points, which mean little in the grand scheme of things, and are usually not even indicative of how well your nation is doing, usually they just mean that you 1. haven't done anything, which includes: diplomacy, loans, changing your capital, changing your ideology, going to war, moving troops, raising troops, colonization, tribal migration, etc. (Pretty much everything in the entire game is lcoked behind a pricetag of these points) or, 2. you happen to own certain high-value provinces which, I might add, are pretty much all in very questionable locations across basically only the western world or China. Meaning it's borderline impossible to successfully play and dominate as a non-white or non-China nation, especially in the modern day scenario, which I might add is not only very outdated (which I'll let slide since the game hasn't been updated in years) but also have some...VERY poltically questionable choices. So, Mr. Lukasz: You placed a ton of valuable provinces in Russia, labeled Putin's regime as a democracy, and made them essentially unstoppable unless you have already conquered basically all of Europe or Asia first? I see what you did there, you dirty bastard. (Okay, but in all seriousness, the ideology part of this game means essentially nothing other than "ooh, look, my flag changed!" and is imbalanced in a way that essentially makes it pointless to even be certain ideologies, and the way that nation power is calculated is skewed in a way that literally can never produce historically likely results.

Now for the gameplay. I already touched on some of the functions of the game already, but one of the biggest flaws in the gameplay is that there is absolutely no strategy. The only way to win is "big number beat small number". There are never any underdogs except through the rare case of sheer luck by conquering/colonizing their small neighbors. Now let me ask a question. If I am at good relations with another country, have an alliance with that country, hell, even have a literal non-aggression pact with them, then WHY WOULD THEY DECLARE WAR?! I am completely convinced that there just actually is no AI in this game, and that Lukasz set up a twelve-sided dice as the nation AI's, with at least eight sides being "randomly declare war on random neighbor and then die". Also, the zoom feature sucks and having a turn-based grand strategy game only works in the Civilization series, not in an EU4 clone. 

Now this is just my personal opinion (which is allowed to exist on reviews, by the way) but although I was mostly cutting Mr. Jakowski some slack when I used to play this game because of his English non-first-language status (some things are misspelled, including some country names, a few country names even have missing characters or incorrect text formatting), and because of the game being kind of old and outdated, the choice to force you to literally assimilate other races of people (which, from the scream sound effects that play when you execute the action, makes it seem like you're purging them) is alarming. There is no such thing as multiculturalism in this game and I'm concerned for how that will poltically affect the minds of people who play this game nonstop. Okay, political BS over.

Overall, I could go on for hours about how this game frustrated the devil out of me, but I digress that it would likely be a restatement of what I've already said.

For the love of whatever god or lack thereof you believe in, do not play this game. Go buy Hearts of Iron 4 or Crusader Kings 3 and learn how to play. Please, for Pete's sake. There are thousands of quality mods for those games that could give you whatever experience you could dream of in a map game. Or, if you're a more casual player, get one of the games in the Civilization series, it doesn't matter which one. Please leave this mobile game port hunk of junk alone and save your five dollars up for a better game. The pricetag of the aforementioned better map games is absolutely worth it. 

And if you're too young to afford them, just literally don't play grandstrategy games. Kids shouldn't be simulating a modern day WW3, they should go have friends in the real world. 

Play a better game or touch grass. Your choice.

Overall an intresting game but it stands unfinished and full of bugs and glithes. One glitch you need to watch out for is the ally glitch. I'm not really a genre vet, as much as I try to be. But I don't think this is going to do the trick for those who are genre vets. This is almost akin to "my first Grand Strategy", something you could use to introduce newcomers thanks to its approachability and free-for-friends remote play hosted multiplayer. But I'd definitely not recommend it to people who play HOI4 or Crusader Kings to get their rocks off.

Balance is finicky - it took me a few goes to start winning a game on normal difficulty but then there was nothing in the entire game that could threaten me.

For some reason, starting unit counts are randomized, so I might get none and other nations get hundreds, restart, totally different setup even with identical nations. This is one of the more noticable way AI exploits the game in an asymmetrical way.

AI will throw themselves into a situation they can't win as if their programming tricked them into thinking it would work. Repeatedly. They're not really trying to outsmart you just throw numbers at you regardless of your own. They rarely split units, or reinforce smaller numbered forts. They almost always attack even when they should be on defense.

Tying movement points to construction building means you can't build as many things per turn as you could otherwise, and if gold excess is such a problem you need to artificially limit how much I can spend per turn, then lower how much gold is given out lol.

Regarding naval movements; units can enter islands from the sea but cannot enter the sea without a port. THERE ARE A LOT OF ISLANDS that are isolated territories so have fun building a port for every single one.

Regarding the game's says-on-the-tin-simplicity: It might be too simple. There's only four things you can do; build something, make or move units, fiddle with economy sliders, and (really REALLY barebones) diplomacy.

Another thing that annoys be is that if you select a territory, then click another, it'll try to move the units even if you didn't hit move. It's really annoying and makes it hard to skim through territories, which should be easy.

I dunno. It's a cheapy and might be fun to remote play with your friends, since there's only one copy needed it's the cheapest multiplayer grand strategy there is. But the simplicity, fiddliness and wonky difficulty makes it very difficult for me to recommend for solo play, but I found it a lot more approachable than HOI4 so, it has that going for it.

It's pretty clear this game is finished, with the final few updates being some rather high quality maps. I don't think this would even be worthwhile on a mobile device. On PC especially, you can do a lot better for five dollars. I'm convinced the AI makes decisions on a roulette wheel, and the game itself is raw numbers, like Risk, only saddled down with features that beg for a different system. I remember playing the first game on bus rides back in high school and it was great for setting simple goals and accomplishing them. This just feels unfocused.

If you're looking for a fun, turn based grand strategy that tries to accomplish a lot of what AoHII does, and like me, feel awful buying anything published by Paradox, look for Field of Glory: Empires. It's eight times this game's price, but well worth it.

Age of History 2 is a fun game to play but as a strategy game its pretty basic. There are a few things missing  from the game that would improve the overall experience so much. One thing i wish they would add is a encirclement system, it would make encircled units do less damage and the non encircled units do more. Another thing i wish they added was a weapon system and different types of units, such as aircraft and naval units. The final thing i wish they added was multiplayer, although it is fun fighting the bots fighting players would be a lot more fun. Also if you could fix the trading bug that makes countries declare war on each other no matter what it would improve the experience. Ignoring my complaints for the game i would highly recommend it to anyone who just wants a fun and easy to get into strategy game.

I love repeatedly getting invaded by countries half way across the world. Playing tall is also very fun clicking on every single individual province to build a building it's almost like most games don't have a building system to prevent having to take 10 minutes to industrialize your country. I was also invaded by Nigeria, Angola, Iraq, and Belgium which I completely love because it makes absolute logical sense that Finland an Afro-Arab country which is a historic region of the Benelux should be apart of these nations. The only war that I had against ai aggression that made no sense was against Norway because I don't see how an Afro-Arab country which is a historic region of the Benelux would be apart of Norway in any way at all very unrealistic. And after this game I honestly wanna try playing on a higher ai aggressiveness level because all that was at the lowest level and I'd always find myself getting attacked by some random ass nation half way across the world who would send their entire army just to take me over dedicating their whole economy to see the end of my nation when I've never had a diplomatic interaction with them prior and I really didn't care about them trying to play tall that game. And untill now I have never appreciated the Eu4 and Hoi4 building systems so much being able to click on a building I want to build then provinces to build them on which is a lot more efficient then clicking on one province then the building one province then the building on province then the building and so on. I also cannot wait to try out using max ai aggression so I can be invaded by multiple nations half way across the world like Tonga, Guinea, Bissau, Afghanistan, Bhutan, El Salvador, and more while playing Lithuania. The ai makes it seem like I insulted their whole blood line attacking me constantly with such hatred. I mean maybe I'm stupid because from school I was never taught how Finland is a very integral part of the Iraqi state but I believe that this game defintely can justify how that makes sense I probably never learned enough history about how Finland is a very integral part of Belgium, Nigeria, Angola, and Iraq just as it would make sense for Bulgaria to invade North Macedonia.

AOH2 is one of the most entertaining strategy game I ever played.

Throughout several occasions I felt I was on a "trip" completely detached from my body... A freaking good game, sorta addictive. 

Most of the cases I applied a merely simple tactic which proved to be efficient in continuously striking deep into the enemy's lines. Advancing towards the enemy's frontiers, and maintaining a well-coordinated push, utilizing the principles of blitzkrieg and recruit in every single turn. Simultaneously, having a backup plan to secure the territories are being conquered. Once a province is captured, strong defensive units are left beind to impede any counter-attack. A "worm" tactic in steps. One army is always followed behind by another aided with recruitment.

At this game the learning curve is relatively gentle, allowing players to gradually grasp the complexities of the game as they progress. However I would not play it while suffering from ADHD... just these loads of details and attributes, not for everybody.

10/10 game

I have only played this game for the achievements. I get an adrenaline rush and annoyed whenever some nation suddenly attacks me without warning but I guess it's fair since players also do it lol.

Customization is superb though I must say, being able to create nations, edit them, as well as redesign the map completely is great, I haven't played with those mechanics but those who want to create a world of their own, do a bit of self RP and all I can see them enjoying. (I haven't tried to rehaul or edit the Earth map of this game so I am unsure if you are able to do this, but I was able to create my own nation in this game).

Overall I can see someone enjoy this if they like creating their own universe or nations, though to me trying to get the achievements is such a hassle, it was more challenging with the random AI behavior. I won't say it is as Easy as Hearts of Irons IV but the customization can make it easier. It is just simpler than Hearts of Iron IV and not too complex as the description says. It did challenge me a bit (loved and hated the challenge it gave me).

Currently, it seems as though it has not been updated for about 2-3 years. Unsure if it is worth the $5 but seems reasonable than Hoi4 DLC's and all lol. So up to you if you want to give it a go. I am unsure if I want to play this in the future but maybe if I get the inspiration to create a world and other nations then I probably would come back to it. Hope this review helps you!

If you demand a low-level strategy game with merely consists of some basic dynamics, that's the game you're searching for. I'll quickly classify the positive and negative aspects below to provide an insight into the [b] Age of History 2 [/b] . Let me start.

[u] What are the positive sides? [/u]

- If you like map-based strategy games, you could like to play.
- It's easy to grip the logic of the game through straightforward game interfaces.
- It has a relatively cheap price
- It's open to customizing and modding

[u] What are the drawbacks?  [/u]

- If you are keen on complex strategy games. That could be a boring game experience.
- Game repeats itself so much after a liminal point. 
- The wars depend only on numbers. Due to that, reacting of the game to the impacts of your strategy feels so bland.

I played this game for hundreds of hours on my phone as a kid - even downloaded apk mods for it with different maps and mechanics. I've pretty much mastered this game, and I'll tell you the worst part about it: this game is shallow. The work is excellent; Lukasz did a great job making this sequel a significant improvement from the first game, but if you have a pc that can run it, you can just play Crusader Kings 2 for free or buy another strategy game with much more depth, the most similar to this one coming to mind being Europa Universalis 4. But, if you are forced to play this be it by system specs, zoomer brain, or platform, it's a great time waster. you can spend tens of hours doing different little strategies and just messing around. Guides online will tell you how to edit the game to put in your own fantasy realms to play with, Vassals are very satisfying, It can feel like I'm commanding and expanding an iron curtain of sorts. You can scatter or solidify and paint the map as you like, within the confines of the bulky provinces. With mods you can truly make border art with tens of thousands of provinces. Hearts of Age of History 2 on the AoH2 website is phenomenal with more advanced coding to include capitulation and a truly terrifying China on such a large map. For Lukasz or someone else wanting to speedrun the achievements like I just did; There is a bug with the AI. If you release a vassal that was never on the map before, they will always give you infinite money so long as they like you enough. This coupled with the inability of the AI to ever trade away land makes the game less enjoyable overall. This bug coupled with another that manipulates saves allowed me to get all achievements other than the conquering ones in less than 4 hours. Congrats and thanks to Lukasz for this game. Entering and exiting the editor after exiting your game will make a temporary scenario, with only the world armies reset. You can then make a new game where you left off, circumventing the save break that can happen after too many turns. Finally, it would be wise if another sequel is made to make the player lose the game when they reach 0 provinces automatically. If in an alliance, or sometimes just on your own so long as you're the defender in a war, you can convince the AI not to take anything, ask for reparations, or otherwise.

It's a great game, its indie grand strategy game like Hearts of Iron 4 or Europa Universalis 4. This game does it all, if you want WW2 this game got it, if you want 1444 EU4 start date this game got it, if you want to play on another planet you can. You can make your own maps, scenarios, countries, etc... But this game is still ass. It has huge potential but developer just abandoned game, ever since i got it nothing was added or changed (maybe 2 or two scenarios that i played once and never again). There is so many annoying bugs. For example if you annex vassal while they are at war every territory they occupied in war will become their owned land and they will have truce with you, instead of annexing vassal, removing them from you and transfer land they occupied to your occupation. There is bug where country names go all over the place and you have to turn them off. If you are at war with x country, and x country gave military access to y country, and you attack territory of x country while y country troops occupy that province, they will declare war on you, this might not seem like a big deal but it is game breaking sometimes. You might not understand what i wanted to say, but point is that there is too many game breaking bugs and annoying bugs that will never get fixed, there are exploits that will never get fixed. 

Where is workshop page that was promised back in 2018? I first played Age of Civilizations when i was 12, when this game came out i bought it right away, but i guess that developer saw it more as quick money grab rather than passion project he will work on. 

If you want map painter to relax yourself a bit, then grab this game, otherwise its trash.

Different ideologies with different effects
Relatively large modding community which adds different systems and nations
Several scenarios
Relatively accurate historical maps
Formables which create a goal to aspire to
Many languages supported
Create custom scenarios, nations, formables, and more

Negatives:
Abandoned by developers
Either lose immediately or conquer the world after several hours
Several systems are underdeveloped and easy to manipulate
Easy to reach 1st place on the leaderboard
Formables have little effect other than changing names
After some attacks on a country, they will either summon a billion units or have nothing
AI is extremely unpredictable

Presonal review: 8/10. The game is fun in the beginning stages of it, but loses that flare when you keep going after your win is practically guaranteed. I'd rather use modded versions, because that community is still alive and adding new things to the game to keep it fun and difficult. I wish this game was expanded on, I can see a lot of potential for where it is now that unfortunately was not done by the developers.

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
¬Ω teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ¬Ω cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

Very good game. It's the prefect game for those of us who like grand-strategy map games, but do not want to spend 13 hours just building up an army to get crushed 40 minutes into your first war. The longevity of a single play-through depends heavily on 3 factors 1. How strong is your country at game start? 2. What difficulty are you playing? 3. What do you want to conquer/accomplish?
Campaigns (playing as one country in a continuous game) can last anywhere from a few hours to a week or 2.
The only major criticism I have is that on the lower difficulties, when playing as a nation ranked ~40th-1st it is very easy to get so powerful that basically nothing other than massive coalitions feel like a challenge. Id recommend always playing on at least regular (avoid beginner) difficulty for play-throughs as nations ranking in the top 40 powers.

It also lacks a great amount of common sense features. If your vassal gets attacked, you have to manually declare in their defense rather than being pulled into it. You cannot integrate vassals, you have to either attack them (and cause any other vassal see you as evil) or "form a union" which only worked once with an ally in my playthrough. Even though my vassal was at +99, they still denied.

As a big fan and avid player of history strategy games I wondered if this game could "tickle my pickle" when it comes to games in that genre, with plenty of hours (900+ combined for CK2 & 3) playing games with intricate systems and strats.
At the FULL whopping price of 4 euros and 99 cents I imagined the risk was low and took a chance.
The expectations were low and I imagined that if it was not up to my liking then no harm done.

The game speaks of "Easy to learn, hard to master" and indeed the game is not too difficult getting into; quick look through the tutorial and off I went.
1200 start as the Mayan culture, found myself warmongering through lands yet still making an effort building up my civilization through research and investments as well as building defenses.
1 day, 12 hrs in and I now have my Mayan realm stretching from modern Mexico down to Nicaragua owning nearly all of the land and having vanquished at least 2 very powerful enemies that were a very hard challenge.
I only stopped playing because of my other passion: Formula 1 and the race that was about to start.

In short I can highly recommend this game if you are looking for a cheap and fun strategy game!
It's not the most intricate or expansive game in terms of ways to develop your realm but for this price you shouldn't expect it to be!
So far I can really enjoy and endorse this game, especially at this price and from what I have experienced so far I would have even been ok with paying double the amount and would still have given it a recommend!
With several scenarios / era's / important events in history to play with. there is a very high rate of replay value.

If you're like me and you love history, games set during historic times and love a bit of RP during a history game then this game is a steal and a no-brainer!

Very good indie game. It's hard to believe it was only made by one person. Also does anyone know what happened to the developer. Anyway, this game is like the game Risk, except their is way more depth and skill involved. Totally worth the money.

Reasons why this is a good game...

Large scope: Age of History II offers players the opportunity to control and conquer entire civilisations across the globe. Players can lead their chosen civilisation to greatness, whether it be through military conquest, diplomacy, or trade.

Customizability: The game allows players to customize and create their own maps and scenarios. This feature provides endless possibilities for players to create their own unique worlds and scenarios, which enhances replayability.

Historical accuracy: The game is known for its accuracy in representing historical events and civilizations. This not only adds educational value but also enhances the immersion of the game.

Multiplayer: Age of Civilizations II offers multiplayer options that allow players to compete against each other. This adds an extra layer of excitement to the game as players can see how their strategies compare to those of others.

Overall, Age of Civilizations II is a well-designed game that offers players an immersive experience and a lot of customization options.

:::Updated Review in 2023:::
Every now and then I come back to this one, hoping that the community has working solutions for the built-in deficiencies, especially the save and load bugs. No solutions have been found, and the game has actually gotten more buggy as tech changes. It used to be rare that people had problems loading the game at all, but now it seems to be the dominant problem.

My thumbs down has to stand. The developer carried this project 95% of the way and ghosted. As of now, it's been years without a captain or updates, and there are still 1500 people in-game on a Monday morning. Incredible. I would milk this cow while making a bigger one for the fans. My fascination with what the hell is going on here is unending. I hope the dev isn't dead.

:::Original Review::
It's been years, and this otherwise wonderful game still suffers technical issues regarding saving and loading, among other not as severe issues. There appears to be an ineffective level of garbage collection happening, resulting in bloated memory use over time and an eventual crash. The auto-save feature eventually breaks and begins attempting to save, unsuccessfully, every turn. Turning off auto-save in favor of manual saving is useless, as upon loading, your game will be different, down to the empire you're playing.

Check my time playing. I did try to make this work out. For some time, I managed to jury rig it enough to be able to play, mostly through using a specific map and game settings. What I had to do is lengthy, and worked maybe half of the time, and does not work on the test version.

In the end, it's a broken product that shouldn't be sold if the company isn't going to support it and release patches to fix crippling problems in a timely way. The discussion area is littered with save/load issues, and the test version is in development hell. Good outcomes, so far, have not been a thing.

They went 95% of the way and called it quits, it seems. I can't recommend this product. What a shame.

Age of History II is a very simplified version of Paradox games such as Hearts of Iron IV.

It's really fun for the first 5 hours, but then it becomes repetitive because it's almost impossible to lose‚Äîeven on the hardest difficulty. The AI complexity doesn't change at all, you just have a harder time making money so you're an easier target. But being attacked can be avoided by just spamming "Improve Relations."

That's it, that's the entire game. It's just spamming buttons and colouring your map. The only reason why I currently have 50+ hours played is because of the formable nations (Italy ---> Rome), but even that gets old really fast considering how few of those formable nations there are. Some of the greatest and most infamous kingdoms and empires are even missing.

Not to mention this game hasn't seen a proper update since 2020, so there's plenty of annoying bugs such as your camera randomly jumping to the corner of the map, or the names of nations getting jumbled.

This game also loves to throw random declarations of war on you, even though the nations are worlds apart. Sometimes I can't even tell where the invading country is, because the game doesn't mark it. That way, all you can do when a speck of a nation attacks you, is watch in bafflement.

At the end of the day, Age of History II is a good game if you're scared by Paradox's complexity, but the cons outweigh the pros, and you will get bored really quick.

Edit to answer OYOLORWT:

Well, a hundred people have a hundred differing opinions. If you enjoy the game, good! But it feels like I discovered the entire game in just 10 hours, the rest is me goofing around.

With such a small (actually non-existent) complexity, what is there to do? I genuinely wonder what you did in the game for 300 hours.

If you play through the tutorial for some 15 minutes, you've already mastered the game because there's nothing else to do here. Just MS Paint this map.

I understand that this game is made by just a single person, but compare it to HoI 4, for example. I've actually seen some people say that HoI 4 sucks compared to this, which is factually wrong. HoI 4 has bigger complexity. You actually have some objectives to strive towards to. You have regular soldiers, tanks, planes, ships...

In Age of History II, if you have 1000 soldiers and your opponent has 500, you win 99% of the time because this game only subtracts these two numbers. It doesn't take into consideration that a single soldier can kill 10 units or die with zero kills. That's how "complex" this game is.

I may sound like a brat, but unlike some of you, I have some standards when it comes to realism, tactics and overall entertainment.

I'm not sure how this game got all the positive reviews it currently has. Maybe it's thanks the the legions of Polish accounts with only this game in their inventories, leaving generic reviews like "good game", "great game" and "good game buy it". Smart one dev, nobody will suspect a thing.

Let's move on.
A handful of time periods to start in, sure. Yes, you can pick pretty much any civ you want. So you've picked a civ. What now? Now it's time to abuse the infinite amount of bugs and oversights and take over the world!
Oh yeah, regarding the "bugs and oversights"...
Puny one-tile AI civs can spawn in thousands of troops that clearly exceed their population. You can ask any country to go to war with another and offer nothing in return. They don't care, they'll accept it anyway. You can vassalise most of the world just by threatening to invade and they'll never call your bluff. If you're at peace for what the game deems to be too long, two random countries will declare war on you (I was very intimidated when Bahrain and Singapore declared war on my North African Empire, believe me!). You can repeatedly invest in the local economy of one province and practically generate infinite gold.
Saves often break, causing your hours of map painting to be completely wasted.
Cancer is apparently an infectious virus.
Within a few months of Covid emerging, coronavirus gets added as another disease in the game. Yeah, that was in good taste. Don't focus on the game-breaking bugs or anything, add new diseases instead.

"Fix the bugs, fix the bugs!" the people cry.
"Nah lemme add another map and scenario instead", our valiant developer says.

It's been long overdue to give this game its well-deserved review in order to thank it for the enjoyment it has brought me. In the following, I will explain why it did and under what conditions it can do the same for you. Like probably not that few players of this game, I originally came from the Paradox Interactive section of the Grand Strategy genre, and therefore there'll be a little bit of a comparison in my review, hoping that this will help to distinguish the specialities of Age of History 2. 
Before getting to the positive aspects of the game that caused my rating, let me briefly mention the problems present, because no game can be without flaws, and I want to be potential buyers to feel well-informed. One of those flaws are of course bugs, of which there are some that I've run into multiple times, but not that many overall. The most bothersome I can think of is the bug that makes the player's units disappear from an occupied province after a peace deal, but that doesn't happen anywhere close to often. Another downside of the game is the almost complete lack of historical flavour, because after starting a campaign from a historical setting, there's really nothing to accompany the player through the centuries and supplying a feeling of change, progress or specific characteristics about each era. There are some mechanisms like exploration, colonialism and a simulation of the Holy Roman Empire, but other dynamics like the French Revolution are missing. The focus is clearly on the 1440 starting point which is also presented as the main scenario whereever you look. This kind of simplicity is defining for Age of History 2, as it aims at a streamlined and basic experience. It therefore doesn't offer any precise micro-management options or deep and realistic simulations, like other games are known for. Also being known to the aforementioned Paradox camp, I sometimes notice myself missing a greater range of functions and an in-depth world simulation, but I want to talk about Age of History like it is and what that means.
Depending on the perspective, this last point of critism can be seen as no disadvantage at all, but instead as one of the core strengths of the game. It actually closed an empty space in the Grand Strategy genre, by presenting an antidote to the massive and demanding PDX canon and allowing players to experience basically the same dynamic, just on a simplified level. As long as it's not about having a micro-detailled and convincingly close-to-life historical cosmos, this game can satisfy all desires, from the typical world conquering quest to trying out alt-history settings. By allowing that, Age of History proves a very friendly game when it comes to the economy of the player, as it's not demanding in terms of real-life resources.  This makes it a perfect substitute for all who lack the time, money or nerves to get into more complex games. Given that it runs like it should, it's one of those games that can only hardly disappoint for what it costs.
The second great advantage is that the game grants the player a lot of freedom in managing thing like he wants to. Not only is it possible to edit many of the visual elements, like names of provinces or colors of countries, to his liking, but the options to get creative are enormous. The player can change existing material like scenarios, countries, leaders and the such, or create his own easily, all of that inside the game. Especially when it comes to creating a scenario, there are a lot of parameters open for adjustment, even some pretty demanding ones like the relation numbers between nations or the make-up of province populations, that demonstrate how simplistic or not this game really is. But it isn't necessary to get into it that deep, there are more important and easier to handle setting like alliances, armies and the such when it comes to editing scenarios. Another feature that actually doesn't come into play before that are events, as there none in the game at start, like I already mentioned when discussing the negatives. But it's possible to use them and the effects can be quite significant, so that's another plus. In the end, it's up to the player whether to create entire fictional realities from scratch and map out every little detail, or just to quickly set up a simple scenario to try out ideas and how certain constellations would play out. It's the closest thing to a historical sandbox that is known to me.
Those are the two main strengths of the game from my perspective, and their combination is what makes Age of History 2 so worthful. As someone who loves to experiment with alt-history settings, it allows me to do exactly that pretty easily while at the same time also offering a lot of potential for precise micromanagement. If your interests like simmilar, chances are high that you'll also be satisfied by what the game offers. To finalise my review, let me briefly list some smaller positives that help this game shine and evoke the enjoyment that it's brought me:
The map is really well-designed. At least when looking at the standard map, it quickly becomes obvious that it was created with the goal in mind to display multiple historical constellations. The borders of provinces fit very well to the different eras and nations, making it easy to play historically. Despite already playing for more than 4 years, I haven't really tried out the other maps (except for the meteorite Kepler, yay), so I can't really say anything about them, but the fact alone that they exist, and also a map editor, as far as I know, is pretty astounding. Another strength of the game is that it never fails to provide statistics and overviews that are easily accessible and help understanding the situation of the world. For instance, there are lists of the wars taking place at the moment, of the population numbers of countries, the casualities of epidemics and much more. Even though some UI elements aren't really harmonous in terms of their size, the graphics are overall well designed and nice to look at. As long as one doesn't expect the same level of stunning beauty that some newer games offer, Age of History is completely sufficient and supplies colorful and expressive as well as clean and comprehensible maps. For me, it meets the perfect balance between nice-to-look-at images and essential substance, it provides both the stories and the style for the alt-history scenarios made.
So, even though my review is somewhat specific in its focus on the main features that I use and its repeated comparisons with the undeniable Paradox competition, I believe that I was able to shed light on the specialities of this game and the ways to use it efficiently that result from that. Being convinced of its quality while at the same time acknowledging the problems present, I felt that I should finally honor this exceptional peace of media and by that pay it back for the hours upon hours I've spent with it. Despite some flaws, despite the lack of certain mechanisms and despite the fact that the developer has stopped to publish patches, the benefits clearly dominate.

Don't let my playtime fool you, although i enjoyed my time with the game it is still a buggy mess and hasn't gotten any updates for 2 years now. Who knows what the dev is up to at this point, I want to be optimistic and say he's working on the game but I don't think that's realistic. If you do still intend to buy this game, please try to find mods for it because the dev sure as shit won't add a workshop to this game.

Age of Civilizations 2 is an impressive strategy game that provides a rich and engaging experience for players. The fact that it was created by just one person makes the game even more remarkable. The game features a diverse range of civilizations, each with its own unique strengths, weaknesses, and historical background, making for a challenging and rewarding gameplay. Players can choose to conquer, explore, or negotiate their way to victory, adding to the game's replayability. The map is vast and filled with opportunities for expansion and growth, making for a captivating and immersive world.

The AI in the game is well-designed and provides a good challenge, ensuring that players always have to think carefully about their next move. The graphics are also noteworthy, with detailed terrain, beautiful cityscapes, and a well-designed user interface. The soundtrack and sound effects are also top-notch, adding to the overall atmosphere of the game.

In conclusion, Age of Civilizations 2 is a must-play for fans of strategy games or history. The game offers endless hours of enjoyment and provides a challenge for players of all levels. The fact that it was created by just one person makes it even more remarkable and a testament to the creativity and passion of the developer. Highly recommended.

its a fun game but is having some bugs

Unfortunately just a mobile game that tries to be every Paradox game in one despite making fun of Paradox games.

Completely abandoned by sole dev with several actually game breaking bugs still in the game, presumably features instead of bugs. Your game won't last more than 2k turns because if it does, your relations with other nations will break and this bricks your save because you cant declare war or do anything.

The AI is barebones and is often persuaded by 27 gold pieces that their "neighbor" from South America offered them to declare war on you, the player. Even though the south american nation is offering 27 gold to an AI in Europe. To declare war on you..
It feels designed to screw you, and only you, the player over.  These checks and bribes are all done in one turn as well, so you can 90% of the time savescum and just... not go to war with a bribed AI.

However, barring that, the game is incredibly easy to cheese after getting a slight grip of all the mechanics. It being turn based means you also have to micro tens of things in one turn for every turn you play, so every save just becomes a microfest that makes HOI4 multiplayer look like a silly spelling bee.

The game also crashes whenever it feels like it, so you better hope you had an autosave.
Age of History II also has a crippling lack of quality of life features. Colonization is easily the most egregious example: you have to manually colonize every province, which, let's admit it, gives you a lot of control over borders and how pretty your nation looks... but it's not fun when you HAVE to click 2 million times on vastly differing places, making it so you're in for actual carpal tunnel syndrome.

The ai also does not have any preprogrammed checks in peace deals like "will this be an enclave completely surrounded by someone else's land?" and so bordergore is the norm... prepare for a headache. And also, stronger AI nations sometimes chill out, letting small minors become stronger... there's just, nothing to be found here. Every AI is a speedbump for you to go over, some are stronger than others but they're still just speedbumps.

Diplomacy is also garbage with AI insulting you diplomatically, lowering your opinion and severing relations, to be frank, absolutely RANDOMLY. Even your own created puppets will insult you and if the relations go into the negatives, they'll suddenly start craving freedom, and declare it. There are more diplomatic options than, say, HOI4, but they all suck and only one is worth using: declare war. What does that say about this game?


The combat, which you will be experiencing for 90% of the game, is also just hot garbage. It's 100% "who has more numbers?" with a little bit of "well you're on a mountain so the enemy needs a couple more men to kill you" sprinkled on... but it is genuinely 99% of the time just a matter of having more men than the enemy.  There are also thousands of provinces ingame, which you will have to manually capture for a 'world conquest'... I never got farther than conquering a continent before I was either stopped from playing by the 2k turns bug or sheer boredom of knowing I'll beat anything through a war of economics anyway...

Recruitment is only possible on owned provinces, so have fun pushing deep into countries (you cant see how many troops an enemy has unless a tile has a watchtower) with your 3k men hitting the AI's 24k man stack and dying... resulting in the collapse of the invasion because you can't recruit in occupied territory.
Like, this game has one bad design decision after the other just everywhere.
Colonization is too accessible, with it being too easy for even minors to get colonies outside of Europe. Every game will have minors chill about and most likely go for anything that's neutral territory... so, Africa, America, Pacific, etc...

The game easily gets boring and tends to become a power fantasy. I do applaud that the game lets you choose what provinces/tiles to release puppets in and even lets you create your own puppets' flags but this isn't nearly enough to overcome the game's several flaws. In fact, this flag creation is a bit barebones with lacking symbols and flag backgrounds. The flag customizer itself is also janky.

While it is a "Lite Paradox Game" that's easy to pick up and have... well, 'fun' in heavy quotation marks, it's still just a bit too lite. It's a game that makes you want to think its not that shallow, that it has depth - but fails at it, and it shows. About as wide as a puddle, and as deep as one.

3And God said, ‚ÄúLet there be light,‚Äù and there was light. 4God saw that the light was good, and he separated the light from the darkness. 5God called the light ‚Äúday,‚Äù and the darkness he called ‚Äúnight.‚Äù And there was evening, and there was morning‚Äîthe first day.
6And God said, ‚ÄúLet there be a vault between the waters to separate water from water.‚Äù 7So God made the vault and separated the water under the vault from the water above it. And it was so. 8God called the vault ‚Äúsky.‚Äù And there was evening, and there was morning‚Äîthe second day.
9And God said, ‚ÄúLet the water under the sky be gathered to one place, and let dry ground appear.‚Äù And it was so. 10God called the dry ground ‚Äúland,‚Äù and the gathered waters he called ‚Äúseas.‚Äù And God saw that it was good.
11Then God said, ‚ÄúLet the land produce vegetation: seed-bearing plants and trees on the land that bear fruit with seed in it, according to their various kinds.‚Äù And it was so. 12The land produced vegetation: plants bearing seed according to their kinds and trees bearing fruit with seed in it according to their kinds. And God saw that it was good. 13And there was evening, and there was morning‚Äîthe third day.
14And God said, ‚ÄúLet there be lights in the vault of the sky to separate the day from the night, and let them serve as signs to mark sacred times, and days and years, 15and let them be lights in the vault of the sky to give light on the earth.‚Äù And it was so. 16God made two great lights‚Äîthe greater light to govern the day and the lesser light to govern the night. He also made the stars. 17God set them in the vault of the sky to give light on the earth, 18to govern the day and the night, and to separate light from darkness. And God saw that it was good. 19And there was evening, and there was morning‚Äîthe fourth day.
20And God said, ‚ÄúLet the water teem with living creatures, and let birds fly above the earth across the vault of the sky.‚Äù 21So God created the great creatures of the sea and every living thing with which the water teems and that moves about in it, according to their kinds, and every winged bird according to its kind. And God saw that it was good. 22God blessed them and said, ‚ÄúBe fruitful and increase in number and fill the water in the seas, and let the birds increase on the earth.‚Äù 23And there was evening, and there was morning‚Äîthe fifth day.
24And God said, ‚ÄúLet the land produce living creatures according to their kinds: the livestock, the creatures that move along the ground, and the wild animals, each according to its kind.‚Äù And it was so. 25God made the wild animals according to their kinds, the livestock according to their kinds, and all the creatures that move along the ground according to their kinds. 26Then God said, ‚ÄúLet us make mankind in our image, in our likeness, so that they may rule over the fish in the sea and the birds in the sky, over the livestock and all the wild animals, and over all the creatures that move along the ground.‚Äù

However, the game is plagued by bugs that can be frustrating and even ruin your whole game. Additionally, it seems that the developer has stopped working on the game, meaning that no future updates or bug fixes will be released. Despite these issues, I still consider Age of History 2 a very decent game.

Incredibly clunky. 

You get a lot of notifications for wars, buildings, investments, etc.. but you can't right click to dismiss then, you have to manually left click them (Right clicking ended up having me move random armies to places I didn't want, wasting turns), and there isn't a mass-dismiss for them either. This becomes increasingly problematic when your mapmode gets changed consistently when clicking through the notifications.

I like having a scroll bar for things relating to the economy, but troops definitely need a 25%, 50%, etc.. button, otherwise it's just too taxing to micromanage.

On the topic of micromanagement, dear lord. Each province allows you to construct individual buildings, as well as to invest, set up festivals, etc.., which is neat, but there isn't a larger panel that allows you to see all the provinces you have a specific build available (Ex. all provinces that you can host a festival in at once time), so having to click each and every individual province to, using the festival example, host a festival every seven turns. Likewise, for festivals and investments, an option to set favourite provinces would be great.

Lastly, I decided since I was going to test out their in-game cheat system and was impressed on how the cheat system actively makes you not want to use it in regards to the "army", "movement" and "money" options, and without being able to set an actual value, the default makes it woefully inefficient, and rather tedious to use

Overall, I'd say this really wasn't worth the purchase, even on discount. I didn't like some things about it, but I'm certainly going to uninstall for now.

Edit: Crashed when I was about on my way to conquering my 50th province. So that's nice.

Whenever i start playing this game i need to be like "quit the game now while its fun or be angry at the AI and the game". All my problems with the AI:
-the AI¬¥s strategy is so bad, its just "replicate in all possible territories and be a pain in the A##".
-The AI is just randomly generating diplomacy answers (Eg.: a +72 relation civilization sends insults and plummets your reputation with him).
-The AI pulls troops out of its a## to defend a territory,(Eg.: im attacking Beijing and China Recruits 10000 Units, making the game more impossible)
these are all the problems with the AI. heres the gameplay itself:
-the combat system is bad. its just basic maths.
-Repetitive gameplay (declare war, annex its territory).
-its almost impossible to create a  Superpower by yourself (mostly because AI problem one and two).
I think i just said all the bad parts of the game, heres the good parts:
-there are formables
-not bad graphics
-Map editor
-customizable Autosave (you should see my face when Endless Space 2 crashes and need to load up an autosave +20 turns before the crash)
thats all for now...

if anything changes (hopefully) then post it in the comments, i will change this review accordingly.

This game is very fun whilst playing with the default scenarios. But that's not it, as you can create your own scenarios and civilizations which give close to infinite possibilities. This makes the game, in my opinion, the best low-budget grand strategy game you can buy. It runs smoothly almost all the time except for multiplayer campaigns. It also was extremely easy to setup, unlike Hearts Of Iron IV which, for me, couldn't be ran because the Paradox Launcher broke. The only thing i'd really want the game to add is split-screen multiplayer and more scenarios, but right now, it is still amazing. Would recommend over any paradox or free to play games.

It can get a little boring from time to time though, but I'm glad I don't have to manage a million things. I basically used my imagination for a lot of things within the game to spice it up a tiny bit to make it a bit more interesting for myself as there aren't really a lot of things to do or really experience. As for bugs and glitches, there is somewhat of a decent handful of them, however, these can be easily fixed or just ignored. If you enjoyed a water-down simplistic strategy game, this is it.

I am a 59 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you <3

This game is worth the $5. It's a very simple game but you can make your own maps or use pre-made ones that come with the game. The different outcomes are limitless and the AI can be frustrating at some times but you can change the difficulty and the aggressiveness. The game play is very basic, recruit, move troops, attack or defend, capture country's or state's and keep going.  But, somehow I keep coming back to this game it's good for  starters who want to get into games like HOI4 or any war based strategy.
it is a good game and has lots of scenarios, even allows you to make your own. Only downside is the developer hasn't updated it in a while but it is a good game still.
Its pretty easy to beat, and the ai is unchallenging. However, it makes up for that in pure scale. I had fun conquering every province in the whole world.

This game is infested with bugs: 

-The difficulty system is completely broken and the "Legendary" difficulty is as easy as the "Normal" difficulty.

-Trades: you can get a country to declare war on another country for 1 coin.

-Sometimes a country would randomly declare war on another country, even though the countries are a continent apart.

-The game randomly crashes (not consistent) 

-and much more game-breaking bugs.

I do however, recommend this game it's only 5 dollars; you get what you pay for. (also forgot to mention the game is kinda confusing for new players, I would recommend to watch a Youtube video on how the game works)

Age of history 2 is a grand strategy, turn based indie game that has multiple scenarios to play or choose from, from the roman empire age to WW2, to the modern world (2018)

Pros:

+ Easy to learn, controls either from mouse or keyboard (shortcuts)
+ A few notable maps, such as: Europe and Asia
+ You can be any nation you like
+ You can create your own nation ranging from name to flag
+ Form civilizations, such as: Prussia as Bradenburg 1440 or USSR as modern day Russia
+ Manage your treasury, such as: Taxes Goods and Economy
+ Full control of your diplomacy, such as: Vassal Taxation, Change of gov and loans
+ Highly mod-able, such as: Create your own type of government, modify nation flags and names, modify the world background, cursor etc... (It's all easy to do once you watch some tutorials and ask the community)
+ Create your own scenarios and custom form-able civilzations
+ Decent amount of replay ability (Just look at my hours!)
+ Spectator mode

The Middle:

~ Gameplay is mostly the same, who has the most units wins the duel. Very simple, I don't mind it but maybe you do
~ Early game is interesting and the most fun, once you become the no.1 nation you are pretty much unstoppable, which can make it a bit boring
~ Not enough victory condition options
~ Leaders never die
~ Mobile Port

The Cons:

- Handful of bugs in this game, even game breaking bugs that ruin your saves BUT you can avoid them
- No more updates are being received, which means this will remain broken and not receive a WW1 scenario in the world map
- Music gets repetitive fast
- The AI is either too difficulty or too easy, no real balance

Overall this game with it's game breaking bugs, repetitive music (which you can replace) and simplistic gameplay has managed to suck me in for 500+ hours!

OVERALL SCORE: 7.2

Graphics: 4/10,... Gameplay: 7/10,... Combat: 6.5/10,... Music: 2/10,... Diplomacy: 6.5/10,... Modding: 8/10

Cause  y e s

[h1] PROS [/h1]
-The community super nice and active (specially on reddit), in fact it's the [i] [u] one of the best fanbases i've been in [/u] [/i] . 

-The game is also ultra-customizable at a point where you can change the intensity of the nation's colors in the map, how visible are occupied provinces... You can even create your own scenarios and formable nations with it's own flag desinger that, with enough time, you'll be able to do wonderful flags and use them with the countries you play. Have you ever wanted to create a "Polish-Mauritanian-Brazilian-Taiwanese Commonwealth" Even with it's own unique flag? Well, you can!!

-The achievements are all extremely easy to obtain, but that's only if you want them to be easy or not, cause' there's a lot of ways of obtaining them.

-AoH's community also offers a sizeable category of mods, such as bloody europe, conquerors, the new era...

[h1] CONS [/h1]

-The game's got some bugs that rank from mere visual bugs [spoiler] like countries names showing above their territory and not inside it. It's not something specially annoying [/spoiler]... To some very annoying ones [spoiler] like a bug where your cursor gets "stuck" somewhere in the screen and when you move the camera to any direction it automatically goes back to where it was pointing before, thus making the it impossible to play, forcing you to restart the game[/spoiler].

-The last update (at least since i posted this review), was launched on the 22nd of Dec. 2020, and with the developer completely out of touch with the community, it's basically an update-wise dead game, pretty much like [spoiler] TF2, being alive only because of it's community [/spoiler]
[hr]                                                                                                                                                                     [/hr]
[hr]                                                                                                                                                                     [/hr]
Overall, I'd recommend this game if you're looking for some easy, and highly customizable game that could be an alternative to Paradox's games.
