This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

i can't recommend this game. there are much better alternatives out there, don't be discouraged by their slightly more complex learning curves. just, look elsewhere. if you aren't convinced:
[list]
    [*] aoh2 is a bugfest, the developer literally does not care about this project anymore. i haven't tried mods and i don't intend to, the model of relying on modders to fix your game is wrong and shouldn't be encouraged. i tried to like the game and at some point i even enjoyed it, but the game breaking bugs just got to me. it hurts especially because the worst bugs happen on long term games, which is incredibly demotivational. 
    [*] the ai is absolute garbage, your alliances and vassals will only bring you down, the decisions made by ai are bs and seemingly random. 
    [*] the tutorial of this game is crappy, the wiki is not helpful at best and non existent at worst. some mechanics are still unclear to me as they were not explained properly in any way. in some games figuring out the mechanics yourself works because it is part of the game design, where in aoh2 this is just poor execution and it hinders the core gameplay.
    [*] speaking of the core gameplay, it's not great. the ui is unintuitive and sluggish. moving your troops around is an absolute pain if you have an army of any size. move your army on accident? great, you can't cancel it now. finding and selecting dispersed troops is rage inducing. generally if you want to do something that affects multiple things at once, you're not gonna have a great time.
[/list]
there are probably more things that i could say or mention about this game, but i think that i get my point across. feel free to correct me on anything that i got wrong, but this is how i feel about the current state of the game, which will likely not change. i haven't tried map editing or scenarios, but i don't want to and i think that it will be a similar experience to regular gameplay.

This game has potential, but the developer abandoned it. Bear in mind that if your gonna play this game, it has a ton of game breaking bugs.

I'll name a few:

- Save games can get randomly corrupted, this happens extremely frequently and you wont be able to access the save back.

- AI spams a ungodly amount of troops, making wars very annoying to partake in.

- You can get declared war on by a country from continents away, even if you don't even border them, this sucks if your playing as a small nation.

- The relations system is broken. You can have relations at 100 and still get war declared on by that country for no reason at all.

- And lastly what I would say is the most annoying bug in the whole game. The last redeeming factor of this game has to be the custom scenario maker, its easy to use, and has lots of potential. Sadly, there are random times when your editing a custom scenario and all the events get messed up and don't work. When this happens you need to manually fix every single event for the annexations to work properly, if you have a custom scenario with many custom events then this is really not good to have. My suggestion is that if your going to play the game and make custom scenarios, only edit your custom scenario once, because if you edit it more than that you might just have to reset all your custom events. You can lose many time that you put into custom scenarios.

Sadly I will not recommend this game in its current state as it is abandoned. If you want to try it out, go ahead! But there are many, many, bugs.

es divertido

I like this game on a certain level, I used to play the first one alot when I was younger. However, cannot really recommend purchases for this game for these reasons:

1. When attacking Rebels, troops will sometimes instead simply convert to the rebel faction instead of actually taking the province, while this hasn't happened many times in normal play for me, it happens almost every time when using rebel nations in edited scenarios.

2. Needs quality of life changes, when typing pretty much anything, there is no way to go back and edit the text, it must be completely deleted and rewritten. The custom flag system for the nation maker is annoying with its overlays being unmovable. There is no easy way to tell what alliances exist or people are in, at least I have not found one.

3. Diplomacy can sometimes be annoying, I have not found a way to remove/end a union made with a nation. When in a peace negotiation, it does not say whether or not the enemy will accept or reject or why so.

4. The event making is absolutely horrid. I have not found a logical way to create an event and have only had one work for me through sheer luck, and even then it was partly wrong. There is no explanation as to how all of the parts of the event making process interact or what they even do. I have been unable to consistently get events to trigger based off anything other than "civilization exists" which instantly grants the event. The province selection in the event making process can only select multiple if you use the brush mode. 

5. I don't remember the last time I heard about an update or bug fix for this game.

While I am sure there are other complaints for other reasons, those are the most apparent for me.

dev abandoned this game.
actual game content is fine for a newcomer to this style of gameplay but quite lacking for anyone else - if you dont have the money or computer specs for a paradox grand strategy then this is your cheap knock-off version lmao
AI is broken, maps always end up looking nonsensical, there are an astounding amount of bugs/errors - every time you think you've seen them all, another one pops up. i won't go into detail as many other reviews have.
this game is definitely most suited for the mobile market, however the steam version does allow a few more features such as modding.
these days i only ever use this game for its map editor which, despite the many bugs, is actually quite decent comparative to most editors out there. i recommend playing with mods, but beware as most mods with promise are abandoned.
overall, buy this if you want a decent map editor or if you dont have the money for a paradox grand strategy but still need to scratch that itch (alternatively if you feel those games are too complicated for your taste, which is completely understandable as i was in the same boat previously). please note i really respect this game as it was exactly this for me - a simpler, cheaper version of a paradox game i brought back when it was released on mobile after already having played the original age of civilizations games, and it was quite fun for a while. i just cannot recommend it in its current state as it has been abandoned for about two years now.

This game is barely acceptable as strategic game only because its cheap.
Developers just released it and leave it away. After many years of playing this game on mobile, I said to my self lets try it on other platform maybe it could be something different and with more content, silly me.
There are many major problem with the game that makes it super easy and boring and also some times a pain in the ass.

AI is really a joke, seriously. Because of the dumb A.I. you can win the game in any difficulty, like for example when you are just a weak country and a random other country attacks you, you never need a good ally to defeating them, just go and trade with other countries that are neighbor with your enemy and that's it. They wont take or want any thing to start a war. they will just accept. 
They accept to declare a war and ruining their own treasure and army and they won't accept to give you a military access even for massive gold. If you don't call this an stupid A.I. then what else could be?

There are many mechanics in this game that could be massive changer in the whole gameplay but they are only usable for decoration like changing government type or technology level. I see no difference if they wasn't in the game.(the diplomacy mechanics are even bigger joke to count in here as problem)

It gets more funny when the game gets easier when you choose a small country. As you choose bigger and more powerful country, the game gets harder. Economy, treasure, army, population and any other things that kinda useful are controlable easier if you have smaller territory and that is a huge buff for you, becuse controlling these things would leads you to victory. In bigger countries you cant barely see a growth in your economy .

And something that really bothered me is the way that AI choose to expand territory. I need a holy water to cleaning my eyes after a looking at the map after 200 turns.

If I was playing this game in 2018, I would definitely recommended this game, but for now...ABSOLUTELY NOT

I'm probably one of the users with the most hours played, and I can confidently say that this game is just not fun. This game is only enjoyable when you zoom out to see how well you painted the map. And that's what this game is, a map painter, it has almost no depth to its mechanics and overall is very shallow in gameplay. Now, if there is an instance where I can recommend this game is as an introduction to the Grand Strategy genre (at least like Paradox does them. I haven't tried many games from other companies yet). This game changed my life (no exaggeration) by showing me a new game genre, and today Grand Strategy games are the ones I play the most. It hurts a little to review this game negatively because of how it changed my life, but at least in this state, I can't recommend it to everyone. The game needs a lot of reworking for it to be actually fun. It tries too hard to be simple, but strategy games can only be so simple before they start being a moving map. If this game started to give up its simplicity for more in-depth gameplay, I could recommend it.

This might actually be the worst game I have ever played. Nothing is user friendly and nothing is intuitive in layout or mechanics. There is far more going on than any player could possibly handle, unless they spend an entire day on a turn. Realism is out the window as the game is just a constant never-ending world war, no matter which era you play and no matter what difficulty settings you choose. Fog of war is always present, even when set to 0. Fundamentally this game is catastrophically flawed. I cannot believe I wasted $15 dollars on this. I should have been paid $15/h to play this utterly trash game. Whoever made this needs a new hobby. I say hobby because if this was their job they surely would have starved by now. I WANT MY MONEY BACK!!!

ok nigga

The game is an extremely buggy mess, to the point of being completely unplayable. Now I can't even start a game no matter what I do without every neighboring civilization immediately starting to take over the whole map when they should not be able to take over even a single province yet. The game has a huge number of other bugs that make it unplayable as well, and the developer just does not fix them. period. He came back after seemingly just straight up abandoning the game, added a single new map to the game without adding anything new or fixing any bugs, then seemingly just abandoned the game again.

Even without the bugs, the mechanics are very shallow and are not very fun at all.

I sincerely regret paying even a single cent for this piece of garbage, and I can almost guarantee you will as well.

The only good thing in this game is the editor, but with how awful the game itself is there's no point in using anyways if you won't have fun with anything you make.

Update May 2022: Stumbled upon the game in my library after a long time, decided to give it another chance. Immediately ran into the exact same game-breaking bugs on my very first session. No substantial updates in over 2 years. This developer is completely incompetent and the fact that [i]anyone[/i] likes this game when it is so laughably terrible truly boggles the mind. Do not support any of this developer's future projects. I am 100% certain they will be just as bad.

I just can't recommend this game. I played some of the other games on mobile as well and all suffer from one issue...the AI plays by different rules (AKA just cheats). I'm struggling to beat normal mode because countries with much less income and economy than me (despite the fact I am usually a massive power) these small AI countries somehow maintain armies much larger than mine, replace their losses much easier than mine, and for some reason the game favors the AI moving first (even if I'm the aggressor in the war)

Why not lower the difficulty to easy, like the casual you are, you may ask?

Because easy makes the AI so brain dead it should be named "sandbox" on easy mode the AI barely makes armies over 100 troops and just barely does anything of note.

TL:DR

AI cheats, difficulty feels artificially inflated, easy mode is sandbox.
Very Gud Game, It's worth the price.

This is an extremely fun, slow burning game. The gameplay and mechanics aren't extremely original compared to games like hearts of Iron IV and so on, but I brush past that, what I see is a game that managed to find a foothold in the saturated genre of war games. The mechanics like army recruitment, province stability and military upkeep gets the game the sweet spot of just the right challenge, although, this does diminish late game (after you take about 40-50 percent of all provinces) when due to the sheer size and amount of economy enables you to recruit hundreds of thousands and still be able to keep a stable income. Which is why I personally dont play a scenario all that much after achieving about 50 percent of global provinces, I think the most fun and engaging part of the game is the beginning, where you slowly pick off smaller city states and build your way up to empires. The attention to detail with each and every scenario having accurate placements of countries in distant and fuzzy times, for example the 14 hundreds scenario, the age of fuedalism, at first I thought it'd just place in half effort countries and city states with a general area, but actually it was extremely accurate, looking at say the island of Hibernia (Ireland) It was extremely accurate with the placement of the multiple controlling regions of leinster, omagh, ulster etc. etc. Even when there was very little documentation of Ireland in this time period, you can tell how much care and passion was put into the detail and historical factuality. And oh how I love the strategy aspect. You usually prepare WELL for even small invasions, as countries have WAAAY more military than you probably expect, long borders are usually the hardest to fight wars on, as your army is spread out across the whole front leading to it being almost impossible to stop a massive army going through one province instead of sparsing out like you had done. The glitches are surprisingly rare for a game that hasnt been developed on for over a year so no complaints here
All in all, really fun to play at the beginning, should've been more done to make sure it's entertaining the whole game. 7/10

I'm playing Age of Civilizations II, a turn-based grand strategy game by ≈Åukasz Jakowski. The game lets you control any nation starting in 1440, though the starting options can be customized. The interface features a lot of map modes, but they are difficult to scroll through and movement orders can be issued by mistake. Movement points limit the number of actions per turn, though this only becomes an issue with very large empires. Units can be recruited and moved, while buildings are placed to increase growth and research rates. The budget can be adjusted to produce more taxes, production income, or population growth. Research points are used to provide a bonus in several areas (population growth, administrative overhead, military upkeep) and unlock better buildings. Diplomatic options with other nations are standard (alliances, defensive pacts, sending insults or improving relations), and the AI is decent enough. Age of Civilizations II is more approachable than the Europa Universalis series, but its relative simplicity means there is less to do during times of peace as you wait for research to complete.
Too addicting.

Finally, editing my review after all this time I can give a better opinion on this game.

Firstly I do enjoy this game. Despite its lack of development, and buggy nature, the developer did go out of his way to make it possible to edit almost any aspect of the game, allowing for unique experiences each play through. 

The thing I enjoy the most about this game is especially its easy game play, which usually makes me come back to it when I have nothing better to do and I want to waste some time. And its even more fun crafting stories from the setting in-game. The controls allow for quick actions, with everything quite easy to do.

This game is, if you can get over all the bugs, a perfect example of what a mobile port to PC should be.

Ok, as a person who sees himself as a "veteran" in this game, I think I can give a rather broad and concise critique and review. I remember playing AoC I on my phone every day, and the moment I found out AoC II was coming out on PC I knew I had to buy it. I was waiting for this game to come out for around a little over a year (2017-2018), the date the game went on sale (2018) on its first day I bought it without hesitation, I was really eager and impatient for be able to play it. I remember that on the date of its release here on Steam the game did have errors (bugs) however the developer released an update approximately a week after the game came out to fix those errors and bugs. However, as far as I'm aware and I remember there have only been 2 or 3 "major" updates to the game, after that, Its pretty much abandoned. Don't get me wrong, it's a simple strategy game, where you have the freedom to create your own civilizations and scenarios and modify almost everything you like, but it also left a lot to be desired. The game hasn't gotten any updates for months (or a couple of years), and there are still a lot of bugs and errors to fix, which unfortunately don't seem like they're going to be fixed by the developer. If you are looking for a simple game where you can make your own stories to your liking, this game may really be for you, but if you are looking for something a little more complex and much more strategic, this game is not for you.

I played the first one for hours in high school years ago on mobile, and that's kinda where the problem lies, this game is just a mobile game for PC. This is also the game i would default to in the event of an internet outage, i don't think I've ever once played while connected to steam.
It is insanely good at killing time when there is absolutely nothing else to do but it pales in comparison to the depths of real strategy games on steam, such as EU4 and Crusader Kings.
I've played every sub-genre of strategy game out there, from halo wars to pharaoh, from Rome Total War to the aforementioned Paradox titles and of course, age of empires, this doesn't begin to weigh in to their category.

For ¬£4 you're honestly just better off saving for something else, there is barely any replayability in this, and if there was, it wouldn't make up for the fact that you end up killing your eyes looking at the dull shade of map constantly.

Every game is the same, pick country, click, move slider, click, next turn, click, move slider, etc etc until you "win"

As my ability to play more in depth and better designed games has increased, my opinion of this has decreased equally.
Also, I know it's a small dev team, but so was rimworld.

So, I have mixed feelings about this game, from one side it is quite a fun product which can kill some time, on the other side... it has no real flavor. This game is mostly just an idea (which is quite good) without anything else. This is not what I would call a satisfying product. While there is some nice elements, it is just "paint a map with color crayons" like most "Grand Strategy" genre, yet this has no deep. The game is laughably easy with unexplained elements that seem to do nothing. Not enough money? Just increase tax. The biggest challenge is playing until finishing a scenario, there is no real reason to do this, it is empty. While I can see this as a nice few minute game, it is not something I would spend much time. No elements of real strategy just do it until it'll be over and for the whole map. Nothing is impactful but money, that can be easily got. If you seek a game to play for a long time, it is not this game. While I would say this: I do not really have problems with my purchase, it is not enough to keep me entertained. The only good deal for this game would be on sale or if you have no other game to buy and are not moved by paying low for an boring title, that is all I have to say.

If you are looking for a fun strategy game, this isn't it. Age of History 2, formerly Age of Civilization 2, isn't very fun and doesn't allow a lot of strategy.

The only way you can develop strategies is if you can understand the rules. This game is full of unexplained rules and hidden probabilities. Development, industry and population is all somehow related, but how? No clue.

Everything is expensive, expensive investments make little difference, stuff like population growth are glacial in speed. Diplomacy gives no feedback. Huge empires start with a fraction of the population per province compared to small states to balance the game somewhat. One of the most popular ai activities is starting 'coalitions' against random states. Don't get confused from EU4, a coalition is more like a war declaration from Civilization. It is often completely unprovoked and just means that every member starts a war with you individually.

The game tries to implement too many features from other games, but fails to make the core game loop fun.

If you want something like this that isn't a bloated confusing mess, buy the age of civilization mobile games. They do the core game loop way better, with population and industry growing way more quickly and war being more fun and rewarding. Conquer the map in an hour, not five provinces.

Yes and no.

It's quite a good game and it's nice to play it. However, if you play a ancient scenario, it's quite annoying. 

i.e. If you play a 1400 scenario, and pick something in America, you will end up playing with a tribe, which is fine. But, if you want to grow to the province close to yours, you have to spend 50k gold and have an 1000+ army, which is insane for a tribe considering you are already spending money to improve your tech, or economy or even population.

So it's mostly hitting space and lots of waiting before you can do anything.

The same applies to Modern World and picking a small country, but for this one, I kinda understand. And yet, you can always declare war to your neighbour and conquer him in order to grow, or if you have a port, you can conquer another country in another continent.

I started a game playing as Macedonia, and after conquering Albania, Kosovo, Montenegro and parts of Tunisia(shared with Netherlands) and Benin, I had to give up Benin to Marrocos, which was their allies. lol

So I was the 40-ish best ranked country in the world and started to get hard to pick another place to grow that would not stand much a chance to conquer. Conquering takes lots, lots, lots, lots of money.

This title is a trainwreck and the Very Positive review score is an absolute joke. I don't know if the Dev made an update and broke the game or had a really promising EA run before abandonment or what, but I wouldn't keep what I played tonight if it were free.

This is a simple game with really basic strategy, In addition unit types, research, pretty much everything is abstracted, which sounds great if you want something quick where you don't have to think too hard. But Age of History II is so unoptimized that it runs slower than most of my complex strategy games. It literally takes longer to open the title and load a game than it did to download it.

The icons on the map are absurd and unadjustable. I can't see anything. I'm playing as England and the icon where it tells me how many troops I have in London covers like 3 provinces. I can't see Ireland at all... it is completely buried under castle icons and flags.

I'm constantly getting popup messages about crashes and failure to load.

I have to exit the game using the Task Manager.

The dev abandoned the game a long time ago.

In summary, this game has no redeeming qualities and it is the worst title I've played in over a year. Don't waste your time on it.

I have poured 300 hours into this game. So let me explain why it is absolutely not worth your time.

A few years ago the game was a decent, playable experience with few bugs that were annoying, but infrequent. Now, however, the bugs have been amplified and are now extremely frequent - making the game completely impossible to play if you wish to go for a long game.

At a certain point (around 1500~ turns) diplomacy will completely break, leaving you unable to either improve relations, or lower them. Another a bug that was introduced recently (and by that I mean around early 2020) was the inability to even save your game once you reached the late game; how does something like this happen you may ask? Neglect. The developer has completely abandoned this game and the community that has formed around it - he has been begged for YEARS to fix his horribly broken game, only to silence people who criticize him on his own forums.

Rumor has it he's making AoH III, a game I will not be spending my money on given his track record. If you want to play this game, I recommend you go to the forums and download a modded version of the game for a far better experience because quite frankly, this is a scam.

[b]Age of History 2[/b] is, at the end of the day, a "map painting simulator." It is the simplified version of [b]EU4[/b] or [b]Victoria 2[/b]. That is what makes this game so addicting. Unlike in EU4 or Victoria 2, you can change history without having to learn a semester's worth of instruction. The simplicity allows anybody to dive into the game and build the empire they envision. The customization of this game is wicked; the ability to create your own scenarios and civilizations allows people to experiment with the world. The only cons to this game are the wack AI. For the most part, the AI makes arbitrary decisions, creating many "border gore" situations. 

Overall a very relaxing and addicting game if you're into history or geopolitics.

This game has some serious problems. Firstly, this game seems to be abandoned by the creator, so any bugs found are something that you either need to hope someone found a solution to or know how to fix yourself. Second, visually this game isn't very good. Normally I can brush that off as it doesn't need to be hyper realistic or detailed; however in this case it is an actual problem as the sheer amount of pixelated crowns, castles and flags make it nearly impossible to actually tell what your clicking on in the area of Germany. lastly, this game feels lacking. It feels less alive than the board game Risk. I respect the work that was put in, I know that this didn't have the same size team if it had more than one person at all working on it. Maybe it isn't very fair to compare this game to other games like the Total War series or the Europa Universalis games but it still is competing with them, on a store front, asking for money. I think that EU Rome and Medieval 2 were better than this. This isn't much cheaper and you would get a better experience than this in those old early 2000's games.

I Had 73 hours when writing my first review. I Now have 141. Whilst, yes, I don't play a lot of games for long periods of time (I play for leisure mostly), I am still an avid and experienced player when it comes to strategy and especially 4x strategy games. From my point of view, this is a rather simplistic game.

But be aware, this is not a bad thing at all: Its a great game for people who want to experience light strategy but don't want to think much, and its a great game for people who want to get into strategy games. It also can have its charm for experience Grand Strategy players; Its simplicity make it a relaxing game to play after breaking your head for hours playing HOI4 or Stellaris.

When it comes to content, it does lack: It soon becomes repetitive, and it doesn't really matter what nation you play as they are all the same from a technical point of view. But that's really the only major negative.

All in all, 7/10. Its good for its simplicity and user-friendliness, but it lacks in content outside of eras and different maps. I Will applaud it though, as it is an indie game, and definitely has its merits for being an indie game.

why am i recommending this god forbidden rts game nothing like hoi 4 or any other rts game? Well... tell me another game where you can start in world war 2 as Denmark, form an alliance with the Irish, annex Norway without even invading them, form the Denmark-Norway nation, then go on to form a union with the Irish forming the Denmark-Norway-Ireland nation, ally with the Soviet Union and the united states, then help them take over the UK, Mexico, Canada, and Sweden, and essentially control the entire world.

This is what happens when you order a Paradox game on Wish. 

The game really looks promising on paper, but disappoints in reality. 
The controls are completely unintuitive and feel like they come from hell. 
You don't really get any helpful explainations for just about anything.
You have no idea, what is happening when something happens.
The AI seems completely random.
The editor was the feature I was most excited for ... but it is just horrible.
Why the hell did the developer decide to create this game on java? It's maybe the most atrocious platform for a grand strategy game that Age of History II completely fails to be.

Simple to learn and if you're into this type of stuff it can be very addicting.

The actual gameplay is very simplistic:
_______________________________
-Economy is basically just bigger economy=more money. The biggest issue I see with this is that in long games where you might want to roleplay smaller states just invest infinitely into their tiles and they get insane levels of economy. This is a huge issue in the 1440 start date with the HRE states. I've seen Ulm have like 60k economy which is absolutely insane for a "city state".

-Development just allows you to invest money into tiles easier and build economy more. It isn't really interesting.

-Taxation is always capped at a certain level and ideologies play an insignificant role in changing the rate you can tax at before your population hates you. So yeah Ideology is mostly just aesthetic.

-War is repetitive since its just whoever has a bigger unit stack that wins. There's no quality aspect and terrain has practically no effect in combat. Peace deals are super annoying since if you have a vassal they will actually take territory for themselves and mess up whatever plans you had for the land you just conquered. 

-War declarations are solely based on "opinion" where the lower the number the more likely you are to be declared on. Sometimes you'll have coalitions of nations declare war on you that make no sense. For example: a Japanese warlord, Poland, Tuscany, and whatever other random nation that hates you might declare war on you for no reason whatsoever other than that they all hate you. This can get annoying, really quickly.

-Assimilation is just click button, spend lots of money, and people happy in 50 turns.

-AI is dumb and will stay at war with another nation for a really, really long time until their enemy is usually completely beaten.

__________________

So yeah. I've spent around 2+ weeks of my life playing this game at the time of writing this. The game needs some work, but that doesn't mean you won't have fun with it. It's a fun thing to kill time with or when you want to create some custom scenarios and mess around in them. I enjoy it quite a bit.

The part of this game I've loved the most is the custom map and nation creator which is actually pretty fun to mess around with and make your own scenarios with. I've tried to script events into my scenarios as well, but there are some glitches with the scripting and some commands just don't work at all. In order to script a set peace deal it takes a great deal of effort and you have to hope to god that the AI doesn't make its own border-gore (which if you leave the game running for like 50 turns it will). So yeah if you want to try that go ahead, but scripting events has a learning curve and I still don't think I even fully understand it. It's just functional enough to script a decent start to a scenario if you want to.

Some general tips:
-Put AI aggressiveness at 50% (the lowest) for a more sane experience.
-if you want to annex all of the land you just conquered but you can't since you don't have enough war score, just vassalize the nation and lower your opinion of that vassal until you can demand annexation (they'll accept if your army is at least a bit bigger than theirs). Then release a vassal again and adjust the borders how you want.
-This game is all about population. If you have a large population, you can make big armies, which means you win.
-Play sandbox mode if you don't want to bother with money and just want to Role-play empire building. Sandbox also lets you end wars with AI instantly so it's a lifesaver if you want to avoid constant declarations.
-You can add your own formable nations and I recommend you do.
-If you script events into a scenario: DO NOT observe it as a spectator or else your events will break and you'll have to fix it manually.

Overall: 8/10

*EDIT at 117 hours* after learning some things* The research I did seemed to denote that the game was abandoned and it's a fun game when it's working but has an unhealthy amount of game breaking bugs that make it either unplayable or just boring and pointless to play. If you wanna chuck $5 at this game, be my guest as it isn't much of a waste but it is a very broken game and probably won't be fixed anytime soon or at all ever. I was able to play 105 hours before running into a game breaking bug. Look up "Age of Civilizations 2 save bug" or "Age of Civilizations 2 diplomacy 0.0 bug" and you'll see more info about the bugs. Straight up makes the game unplayable or pointless to play. The developer replied to a few people back in late 2018 saying that he was looking into these bugs and going to try making a fix. It's January 2020 and these bugs are still present. If the bugs get fixed then I highly recommend this game but until the developer does SOMETHING, mild avoid.

I love and played a lot grand strategy historical games (FOGE, CK3, and before EU4, CK2, even tried IR), and bought this game just because I wanted to give another developer a chance (and money). But after I tried 2-3 times to play this game, the learning curve is too steep, even for a "veteran" like me. Nothing is intuitive in this game, starting from the main menu (I could not figure it out how to play with a specific country, for instance), to the in-game buttons and panels with info (even a slider I discovered by accident you can drag it to adjust how much money to invest, I guess). While I do not mind the plain colors of the map provinces, the UI graphics (buttons, sliders, text, panels, etc.) is horrible and cannot stand it! I cannot play like this, and I regret my investment in this game, as I do not think it will be improved.

This game is good and bad. The AI is super jank so often they will randomly declare on you for no reason. Having an ally in a war is awful, often times they will refuse peace offers if you do not have 100% warscore. Small nations can create these massive armies early game that you can almost do nothing about if you declare war on them. It can be a fun game though. At times you can get into good, balanced fights where it takes more than a monkey brain to win. It can be super easy to become the strongest nation, even if you are a country like Ulm. So if you are into making a big blob of a country this is a good game for you. All in all, it is a good game with a lot of potential. The AI needs to be fixed and perhaps adding events that change the game would be pretty cool. There is a custom scenario ability that you could use to make really cool scenarios, so perhaps there could be a workshop to browse other's creations could happen someday.
fuck this game
addictive

Pros:
-very simple and easy to learn
-large map type variety and scale
-scenario editor/creator
-can be modded

Cons: 
-can get VERY buggy, sometimes ruining a game save or making it unplayable
-allies will want some land after a war even though they didn't do anything
-AI overall is terrible (you will be at war with some nation across the globe with no way of them knowing you, countries will try to expand by declaring war on countries that they don't border, which create awful borders, and the AI can barely win a war)
-Game is too easy, difficulty only changes the amount of troops they have
-for some reason, when the age of exploration occurs, obscure, small nations start colonizing big areas like the Americas and Greenland, but big nations like the British Empire or France won't
-borders are too sharp and make the modern scenario look kinda bad 
-can get boring after a while due too lack of content 
--AI peace treaties are horrible (will almost always have exclaves)
-High Difficulty is Unfair (higher difficulty just increases troop size, not skill, which means a 5 province nation will pull 10000 troops in 1 turn compared to my 10000 I saved up for 10 turns)

Overall, game is way too buggy, worst AI I have ever seen in a game, and lack of content make the game feel very unfinished, but when it is working and the AI isn't having a seizure, it can actually be kind of fun, but I wish there were more things to do like manage technology (tanks, guns, etc.)

Even though this game had a ton of potential and the developer's talent was not even close to being shown, ≈Åukasz Jakowski (the developer) abandoned his creation without any bug fixes or changes to any system. Instead of being a great game, Age of History 2 is a sad story of how a developer wanted more money out of a beaten corpse:

There were promises of:
- Religions
- Better colonization
- Better and more important Holy Roman Empire system
- Better coring and population growth systems
- BUGFIXES
- A lot more flavor and uniqueness to nations

And a while back, during the pandemic, ≈Åukasz just decided to change the name and trick people into thinking that this is a brand-new game. No, it isn't. If you buy this, you are supporting a lazy developer that does not care about his fanbase.

This game is only decent for phones because there is no competition. On PC? Buy Europa Universalis IV.

The "modding" community for this game can't fix any bugs or add other system easily, if at all, because this game is made in Java and the developer has not released any source code, so people are limited to making newer/bigger maps and different scenarios with a somewhat lacking event maker. This is the worst game to modify I've ever seen, and I can say that because I program in Java and have tried my best to do stuff with AoH2.

You should be ashamed of yourself, ≈Åukasz.

This is one game that I play a lot and I enjoy, the main idea is good and well-executed but unfortunately, I can't recommend this game because it has a lot of problems for someone who wants to play it a little bit deeper.

[h1]Pros[/h1]

The game is cheap and all the music is just amazing and fits the ambiance. Even though the main strategy for this game is easy to learn, the way how the game works is what makes it special.  You can visualize your relationships and have a clear understanding of who is your enemy and who is your friend. Everything is logical and when you understand the game, you will have a good time messing around with the stats and economy of your country. 
My favorite part of this game is how dynamic the wars are and how tricky they can get. You have a lot of options in-game like changing your type of government, moving your capital, creating a vassal, changing your country's name, and other things. In-game, you have an entire "window" with tables and graphics where you can see how is your country compared with others and it is amazing.

[h1]Neutral[/h1]

The game's interface is not bad, but it could be better, specifically the menu and it can get confusing when you are changing advanced options. The game gets so confusing that when I was exploring all the options and tools I ended up changing accidentally the population growth of some provinces and there was no option to make it all default again. After that, I had to reinstall the game.

[h1]Cons[/h1]

Now, it seems that this game is awesome, and the idea is amazing, but it lacks the basics.
The game is buggy in a way that it can easily destroy some progress, or you will have to re-open the game to play again. I will say some bugs:
[list]
    [*]One time the game interface simply died, there were only flashy colors. I couldn't do anything and I had to close the game, losing some progress;
    [*]Sometimes, randomly, your units simply perish, and it can affect your game badly;
    [*]If you annex a country and they have units on water, there is a chance of the units stay in that position forever;
    [*]On long games (+1000 turn) there is a small change of all countries' opinions reset to 0 and you can't improve your relationship.
[/list]
Probably there are more bugs that I simply don't remember right now. 
This game needs a real Steam Workshop. If you want more scenarios or mods you have to go to the creator forum and download those via other links. After that, you have to put the mod files by yourself into the game files. All of this is just dumb considering that Steam created the Workshop to made all of this much easier.
I bought the game almost 2 years ago and, as far as I remember, there was only "one big update" that changed the name of the game, deleted all my civilizations (like 300 hours gone, thank you), and only added 1 map, that honestly, I think no one asked for it, with some scenarios, while after that there still bugs. I'm not saying that the developer is not working hard, I just think that if he can't handle all the work, he could maybe get some help, because, being honest, this game without bugs, and with the Steam Workshop implemented is worth a lot more than 5 euros.

Despite being set in 1444, the war mechanics are much more similar to modern combat than medieval, having actual frontlines and whatnot. You're not really told what things do, so most of the time you end up just not building anything. Also, this game has a host of bugs, and the developer seems hellbent on not fixing any of them. Kids, Back in my day, this game was called Age of Civilization II.

Eh, if you have a potato PC and want to get some very vague idea of what EU4 is like, then pick it up. Keep in mind that there are no barriers to absolutely snowball after just a few wars, so it gets boring quickly. I wish the map editor wasn't complete balls as well, I have no idea how the world map was made with such a crappy tool (not talking about the in-game editor).

As for mods, good luck navigating the screwed up forums, they're infested with Wumao bots.

Warfare is not very interesting, because defense is a matter of spawning as many units as you can using money so they can get killed the next turn. In other games of this nature, it's made more interesting by making unit organization a part of your army building, or they make at least more than one unit to play with to make combat more interesting on a tactical level. In this game there are just numbers which represent your army. While yes, it makes AI easier to program, it's at the cost of making warfare absolutely boring.

Diplomacy is just a simple matter of a general opinion number. It lacks depth because there isn't much which can affect this number.

Technology is broken in this game. Basically, if you can invest a lot of money into research you will easily have better armies and economy than nearly everyone else.

Managing the economy is a matter of spamming money into development and production buildings. Use money to get money, hardly any strategy in it at all, and possibly the biggest factor in the snowballing problem.

Notice how everything in this game is centered around money? Yeah, that's quite possibly this game's biggest failure. Money is how you build armies. Money is how you research. Money is how you get more money. Basically, if you can snowball hard into economy you will win as nobody can stop your overwhelming cashflow. How do you get money? Simply by pressing the build buttons. There's no strategy in it.

Oh, and for all of you people who are saying that you got into this game because you couldn't understand any paradox game, then I'd say that you'd be better served by a game like Civ 5 or 6 because they're not quite as complex but have a similar depth.

I can't really classify this game as a strategy game because there is hardly any strategy to it. If you like painting maps, then get it. If you are a paradox sucker and are just curious, then I'd say I probably got more use out of this game than I did a meal for the same price, so get it to waste some time. If you have a potato PC and you want this game to fill the void of all of the paradox games you watch on YouTube, then it's probably better than nothing. But don't get this game expecting a very enjoyable strategy game.

After 200 hours i can give a review of this game, and gotta say, i'm conflicted, the game is fun and i kinda like it, is much simpler than others strategic games and even the price is ok for the product you get. But i can't recommend this game, if you  have the money for this game get it only if you expect this:

Country Managment:
The country menagment is literally three bars for the nation spending (that you can set to the pre-marked settings and forget about them) and province stabilty (you need that to not let develop rebels in the province) and that's literally it, libraries, workshop, you really don't need that (it only gives you small buffs, for only that province)

Diplomacy:
Diplomacy is literally useless in this game, whatever you do it will not matter and the diplomacy is driven by nothing (countries 37546 miles away will hate you and will even declare war on you for no reason whatsoever). 

While you have a massive empire the majority of the times countries with one province will not accept  your ultimatums it gave me a sensation it was coded  to be that way.

Alliances are literally just to get the achievements, if you want  alliances to work expect to give your ally some of your provinces and money to buff them.

AI:
The AI is literally the worse AI i have ever seen in a game, decisions made with no sense, war started without interests, the game is even coded that if you are not at war for a certain time two random nations will declare war at you.

When at war this is the plan of the AI: have a province, try to invade with even 1 troop the provinces sorrounding it. This forces the player to play with a one line front so that in doing so you block the AI, and good luck if you forget to defend a province, the AI will break trough your lines and create a mess made of small troops in every  province. Speaking of, the AI will  always  try small attacks  from  the sea even if it is right in the middle of your country. some of the longer session are really frustrating because of the AI.

Smaller countries will SHIT and i mean SHIT out troops, you need at least the triple of troops you expected to conquer them.

I still can't understand what decides which country will attack first. The majority of the time you will spend 2 minutes to make a plan to attack some provinces and then the AI will milk troops in said province and attack first breaking your lines.

Ally AI is laughing stock, it will be like the normal AI but even if they have massive armies they will leave provinces not defended this makes war with allies three times longer because the enemy will always break their lines and make a mess. Also while the normal AI can go through water just fine ally AI will take like 10 years to do a naval invasion, it's really frustrating for example while invading russia or any country that have some islands around far from you. Oh and don't expect to have puppets when you are in an alliance, they can  attack your puppet and then all the alliance will be screwed up, even the game won't understand what's going on.

Bugs: 
The game is not full of bugs but there are serious ones, for example one that will erase your troops, not  kidding, you have 5000 troops in a province and then poof vanished from existence. Another where the Bars that control the nation spending will often bug out and reset themself  causing instability and rebellions. Some minor bug i can think of is that the names of the nations will  often slide upwards doing a mess on the screen, kinda annoying, and will force you to restart the game to put everything back in place.


The game, for now,  is an unbalanced mess with idiotic AI. Now,  it would be fine if this problems would be patched up, but this game is currently abandoned by the creator, until some serious fix will be applied don't spend your money on this even if it isn't that much.

I don't want to judge no one, even because this review i made is kinda shit xD, but the only ones who i can recommend this game to are people that don't know or mind nothing about game mechanics, or those who get a boner from seeing their nation cover earth.

I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys these types of games, but the game became unplayable for me when it was loading. When it was 99% done loading, the game would crash. Does anyone know how to fix this? I've uninstalled it then reinstalled it, I've verified the integrity of the files, and even used backup files. I've used everything the steam support page told me to do, but nothing worked. Before this happened, it was an amazing game. Fair price, great gameplay, even the create a civilization tab was fun. Does anyone know how to fix this, or even what caused this?

Thanks.

Edit: It turns out when you have too many save files on a crappy computer, the computer can't process all the saves at once, so it shuts down. All you have to do is go into the game's files and delete your saves, except for the ones you want to keep playing on.

Pretty fun, easy to learn to play. I'd recommend this game for someone who wants to get a friend hooked on the Grand Strategy Genre. It's Cheap, Easy and Fun. Some complaints, but they're pretty nitpicky.

Age of History II is like a budget Paradox game. By saying that I do not mean it is bad, it's actually quite fun as you can tell by my hours, however, you'll get more out of a Paradox game than this one.

I recommend this game as an introduction to the genre, however, you could wait until HOI4 or EUIV go on sale and buy those. 

For me, the scenario creation feature kept me coming back. The ability to create your own scenarios and play them without modding the game is really cool. 

A major drawback is inactive development however, there are rarely any bug fixes or gameplay changes. Instead there are new maps which are released every 2/3 months at best. 

Overall, it's up to you. But I'd recommend a Paradox game over this.

Simple, fun and addicting. You can change the names of countries, take pieces of your territory to make into a new country as your vassal (You can select countries from history or just make up a country and make its flag.) You can make some pretty interesting scenarios as there is a map editor. The game doesn't look that bad and the combat is basically Bigger Number = win. (Not every time,  sometimes the smaller number might win if there isn't a big gap between the two forces.) There is some micro management and some bugs, but they aren't gamebreaking and can be easily overlooked. The AI. isn't that amazing and it gets frustrating sometimes. For an example, I'd make an alliance with someone, help them, send them gold and they would send an insult for no apparent reason.

In conclusion, It's an amazing game for it's price and I totally recommend it to anyone who wants to play grand strategy but doesn't want to spend hours to learn what is actually happening. It's a fun time killer.

Where to begin with Age of History 2..?
(Disclaimer: "Money" and "Gold" are the same thing, I might get mixed up a little in the review)
Age of History 2 (changing its name from Age of Civilisations 2) is one of the most simple turn-based grand strategy games out there. From the economy to warfare to diplomacy, everything is easy to understand. There are few mechanics in this game that take time to learn. The game also offers a wide variety of nations to play as, as well as multiple scenarios ranging throughout history. There are two ways to win the game: conquer every nation, or get to tech level 2.0 before everyone else. The tech victory is turned off normally so in the scenario options, you will have to turn it on (if you want). 

Gameplay:
The gameplay of AOH2 is quite simple (shocker, right?). Declare war on nations, lead your troops into battle, if you have more troops you'll win, get the province and eventually take over the other nation. I recommend always annexing them fully if possible, but there are a few times where that isn't the best option.  After annexing them you will have to assimilate the provinces using gold in order to keep them from revolting. 50 turns of assimilation will usually stop any future revolts. As diplomacy goes, pretty simple. You'll get diplo points every turn, use those points to increase (or decrease) relations with neighbours. You can eventually ask them to become your ally once relations are high enough. You can also ask them to become a vassal or unite with you, but vassalization hardly ever works and you are almost certainly gonna have +100 relations + ally in order to unite. It is important to keep in mind that you can only unite once (So far I've found). The economic aspect usually relies on you investing in your own provinces using gold, or waiting for them to grow naturally. You will get gold every turn, from your province's economic score (production), and from population in the form of taxation. Economy and population go hand-in-hand, the more of one, the more of the other usually. Population will grow naturally as the turns increase. Population is essential for warfare (can't have troops without people), so you need to be aware of it and where your population centres are. You can also build buildings in provinces that do a variety of things such as increase population growth or allow sea access for troops. As for as research goes, every point of research (0.01 point) will allow you to increase a skill in multiple categories. For example, you can increase the amount of money you get per month from taxation. The game also features colonization, a powerful tool that let's you gain more provinces without war. You can only colonize provinces that are neutral or wasteland that you border or can reach via the sea. In some scenarios, you cannot colonize without turning it on via options.

Other features:
Some other features of AOH2 include different maps, custom nations, formable nations, region editor, scenario editor, event editor, renaming of nations, and a bunch of other minor graphical changes you can make. As you can see, there are a lot of customisation in this game, which can make for some challenge if the payer wants (ex. start in the arctic as a custom nation).

Exploits:
Oh boy, here we finally are, the exploits. Let's start with some basic ones;
-(This one might not count as an exploit, if so, it is a really powerful strategy) Colonize as much coastline as possible, and then colonize the perimeter of a box, ending on your own border. This will effectively create an area in which no other A.I can colonize within. Once you have the gold, it is yours for the taking. This should greatly help with the expansion of your nation, because you can do it in more areas, and effectively claim any area you incase. This exploit really starts to show if you can manage to colonize the entire coastline of say.. South America.

-Investing in one province over and over again can make you a lot of gold very fast instead of dispersing it throughout your nation. As you gain more gold, investing it into one province will increase your gold gain. But if you keep doing it over and over again, you will quickly find yourself making a ton of gold off of one province (don't forget to increase development in the province too every once in a while, it will make even more gold!)

-Trade agreements: oh man this one is REALLY broken. In a trade agreement you can do things such as; sell provinces (don't even try to buy them the AI will never give it to you), ask to form a coalition, or by far the most broken thing, ask them to declare war on someone else. "What's so busted about that?" I hear you ask? Well, it's just that you can pay them very very little in order to start an entire war. You might as well just ask them to do it for free. This exploit really shines when you have a big neighbour that you want taken down a peg or two.  Just ask every one of their neighbours to declare war on them, and watch the chaos ensue. You can effectively be the puppet master for WW3.

Bugs: 
Now we are onto the bugs section. Bugs are quite hard to come by, but they will start to show up at around turn 2500 (if you make it that far). Once you are past that turn limit it seems like the barrier to keep bugs out breaks. There aren't many, but some are annoying.

-The 0 opinion bug. Seemingly for no reason past turn 2500 most nations on earth decide that they should be set to a 0 opinion of you permanently. This means they are less likely to attack you, but good luck on getting allies once this one hits.

-The troop disappearing act. This one also seems to come into play at any point after 2500. It is very rare, but sometimes, when troops are on a preset movement path to a province (move here function), they just decide to disappear off the face of the Earth. I don't know why this happens, but I have lost 10's of thousands of men to this one. (at least you don't have to pay troop maintenance anymore)

-The 'Corrupt savefile' glitch. This one is very weird, like the others, happens anytime after turn 2500. Sometimes once you come back to a savefile it just doesn't load, at all. It looks like you just lost potentially hours of your life to a glitch, worry not, the solution is simple. Load a different save, exit, and come back to the original 'corrupt' one. Save works fine again. But the real annoying part is once you find out that the glitch will persist on that save forever. So, you will have to load another save and go back to the original every time you want to play it, it's just annoying.

-Flashy nation colour glitch. I don't know if this one also happens after turn 2500, because I have only had it happen once. It has only happened when I tried to change my nation's colour, after I did, my nation stated to have a colour seizure. I learned to never change my nation's colour after that. Thus I never experienced that one again.

Final thoughts: 
After what you just read, you probably think that this game is sucks and is bug-ridden, but you've probably noticed that 370+ hrs played for me now. Yeah, I really enjoy this game, possibly too much. It has a simplicity that not many other grand strategy games have, and that makes it really easy to just want to come in and play a quick campaign, see what you can accomplish. Once as England, I managed to almost entirely encase North America, which allowed me to have complete control over it. You just can't do that in EU4. Just a few hours ago I started as tribal Kongo in 1444 and 700 turns later, I am a great power (and even colonized a bit of Oceania and South America). Again, these things will basically never happen in EU4. You can rise to power as almost any nation no matter the start location or date if you know what to do. Even the regular powers such as the Ottomans, England, Korea, all can have fun campaigns. For that, I can't help but to recommend,

I am a reasonably experienced player in paradox and total war games, and I tell you, Tetris is more fun and realistic than this game. The pretty map is the only pro in this game. 

You can't recruit specific army types ie. infantry, cavalry, artillery etc. You just decide the number of new recruits! 

No fleets! Yup, no visible ships at all... You just move your number (land army) through the sea towards your destination. I guess they all swim together?

During war, you can't see the number of enemy soldiers in the neighbouring province. You're forced to attack blind. Only then you realise either the enemy army is actually 5 times bigger than yours, or nearly non-existent and you wasted your money to build a huge army.

Also, regardless of enemy army number, even if it's 10 times smaller than yours, after your initial attack on them, the ai manages to divide them into almost 1 man tiny divisions and conquers all of your provinces that you did not have an army in. The ai keeps spreading these 5 - 10 men divisions in all directions like a virus into your empire in no time.

Diplomacy is very limited. Conquer or vassalise. 

For tech and research, you only decide how much you want to invest. You don't get to decide what is being researched...

This game is more like a school project for a learning student...

Has soooooo much promise but the developer wont bother.

The few pros.
- It's fun to paint the map a colour of a country because it appeals to my desire to conquer the world.
- Can run on a potato
- The scenario editor allows you to make the game more in-depth than the base game.
- Has a local multiplayer hotseat mode, which not many games do; so that's pretty cool.
- You can watch the history of a game after you complete it. Pretty fun watching your empire grow.

CONS
- Shallow combat system, of which the deciding factor is numbers. No significant terrain, building or actual placement required. Just whoever has the bigger army.
- Shallow economy - It's essentially invest in specific aspects of the society and become the 1# economy in a few years (slightly exaggerated). Not to mention the ai don't invest in particular parts of the society.
- No events or anything, making turns really shallow and dull. 
- No online multiplayer, which could probably save this game.
- Stupid stuff like just going "I guess I'm Fascist now" (in the modern scenario), no political meddling required, no international backlash or any coup, revolt or anything like that. 
- The colonisation system is garbage, just throw money at a province until you get it, literally nothing else.
- No revolts or rebellions. There might be, I think  I recall it being a system, not that I've ever actually experienced it.


Overall it's just shallow, so so so shallow. Nothing has depth.

Alright, this one is hard to unpack.

It is a good game. A good game I can't get the grasp of, but a good game nonetheless.

Scenario possibility is limitless, and you can put together your own if you want to. This, along with the included scenarios, make this game a very replayable game.

Though all these scenarios must come with one disclaimer: It is not an easy game. It takes a lot of work to get used to some of the keybinds, which, if you know them, can make your life a lot less complicated.

You also must recognize that you have to balance an economy and a strong military, which is quite difficult to attain the perfect balance if you are the interventionist that I am in these games. I tend to always invade nations around me rather than stabilizing my economy, which eventually will lead to my country being taken over because my military could not be sustained by my total basket case of an economy. 

Its a great game, but expect to practice a lot to understand how the game works and how you can work that to your advantage. I still haven't figured it out.

For the price tag and size, Age of History II is a great time killer and interactive experience for those seeking a strategy game or diplomatic game where the player controls a nation and can live peacefully, or attack other places for world domination. While it may not be as complex as say Power & Revolution, Age of History II is still a great game to purchase! The ability to create and manage scenarios, such as World War III styled scenarios or alternative history scenarios, give it that extra interactive feeling, and the ability to be ranked against the computer controlled nations based on population, land, technology level, and economic score adds another layer of fun and challenges. I do recommend adding this game to your collection for the size and price tag. It won't break your account or your storage.

This game is like a slightly more complex version of risk. Completely worth the $5 i spent on the game. It can be buggy, I've had entire save files deleted before during random updates, but honestly it's not that devastating to just start a new one. depending how you play you can really overdevelop a very small country, or just increase your pop and money through conquest so any game could last as long as you feel like. By the time my country grows large enough to take on the rest of the world at the same time i get bored and start as a new country. the only thing i really don't like is the assimilation system, i like the concept but it becomes a chore to do end game after you conquer a country, i wish it could be a one time investment. Also the vassalage system pretty much never works, but I don't feel it's a big deal since it wasn't something i didnt really care about. It really does a good job as a casual strategy game. might take a few times to learn how to avoid random giant countries stomping you out, but worth learning. Not as many complexities as most strategy games, but i look at that as a good thing. unique in its genre. 9/10

[b]Age of History (Civilizations) II Quick Review:[/b]
This is a quite interesting and cheap game (2400 CPL). If you like strategy games you lose nothing for purchasing this title, it's quite straight foward (simpler than other games of it's kind such as EU4) and can get quite addictive if you spend a few hours learning and practicing (I have over 200 hours on record by the time i write this review). I strongly recommend playing with your own country as the feeling of nationalism makes the experience even better. Playing with mutiple countries at once does reduce the difficulty curve a little bit, but it's really up to which countries you pick at the beginning, the agressivness and difficulty of the AI and the allies you chose (and make). It's not the same picking Andorra, Georgia and Kiribati allied with Trinindad and Tobago as picking the United States, France and Germany and ally with China and Russia, though i would say it's definitvely possible to win a game no matter which country you pick, if you know what you're doing and the game doesn't bug, which is my next point.

This game has some bugs that might make you ragequit such as the interface not working at times and forcing you to restart the game, game crashes or armies getting stuck for no reason, but most of these can be reversed/avoided  by either using the autosave feature or saving each turn so you won't lose that much progress if those bugs were to happen.
I dare to say that with some bug fixes and new content and features (no more maps please), this game is worth more than it's current price.

[b]Final Rating: 6.25/10.[/b] 
Has some gamebreaking bugs that can make want you to refund the game, but if they get fixed and gameplay is expanded this game has a lot of potential.

p.s. Botswana, Chile, Kiribati and Spain best alliance ever.

Although when i initially got the game i was incredibly dissapointed, mostly in part to a series of game-breaking bugs that were effecting my in-game experience and were subsequently fixed. I've gotta say this game isn't bad at all. and although the tutorial is still brief and in places certainly lacking (based on when i last checked it) once you have the basics of the game down it has the potential to be tens of hours of fun as i myself have had playing alone or with friends via the steam remote play feature, and while yes the AI is really random and illogical sometimes (power rank 326 attacking you when you are rank 1) it also adds an element of randomness to it that you can't seem to find in games like Hearts of iron 4. and while we are on the topic of things you can't do in hearts of iron 4 that you can in here:

-rename your nation
-change the location of your capital
-more in depth economy system rather than pure factory allocation that is hearts of iron 4
-a more in depth diplomacy window allowing for more meaningfull interactions with your neighbours.
-form unions with nations and diplomatically too! 
-playing as an economic powerhouse and not expanding your borders at all is actually viable.
-however for the war interested players it has a good army mechanic
-AN EXTENSIVE editor allowing you to create new map configurations or edit existing ones(alongside the already included maps) create new nations to play as (or edit existing ones) either by forming them, (you can choose which nation can form nations) or by creating a scenario with the new nation in it, as well as creating new leaders for your new nation in wich you can add bonuses to your new leader and select wich nations within the game (including custom ones) will be led by this new leader. 

hopefully i got across the sheer amount of content within the game now in comparison with its relatively meagre price, would recommend                       10/10
