UPDATE: 

TIPS
I have played this game to a point where I can easily go to 1st or 2nd rank in just a few turns after atleast 100 turns. But it requires that you take help from a powerful country either being their vassal (so that you hardly go to war) or be in alliance with them.

To make your game experience easier or better you can use "Trade request" to make countries fight "proxy wars" for you and in that time you can adjust your needs accordingly- you can go to war against the country that is stuck in many wars but at the risk of running into a powerful country that instantly declares war against you.


GLITCHES:
=> The glitches I stated earlier in the old review still persist but I have found workaround them. I prefer not to take a country with lots of provinces at the start to avoid economy bug.

=> The opinion 0 bug is sort of a blessing in disguise as the allied country after 3000 turns starts to send you continuous insults after you are done with war. But with 0 opinion bug this "getting insulted by your ally" (explained below) game design, stops being a pattern.


This "getting insulted by your ally" is not a bug but a game design which is done to reduce the power of an alliance as the alliance between an AI and the player country is easy to quickly turn the game experience stale as you can easily sweep through several games. 
Trick is to be in continuous wars as the insults only come when both allies are not at war together.

=> City names do not persist with a save. However, if you change the name of your civilisation it persists in the save but the list of "load game" will show original names of the countries.

=> The country splitting into 2 or 3 different countries is not a glitch but a rare game design that may occur (usually occurs in small countries that have come out as rebels from a war torn civilisation or a vassal with weak stability) which results in 2 different or 3 different civilisations of same cultural identity and nationality but with three different forms of government. Like Malaysia splits into a democracy and communist regime. I wasn't as knowledgeable of this game design back when I had just been through 100 hrs of gameplay but now I understand this game design very well.

=> Opinion 0 is only a blessing in disguise in case of the Alliance insulting game design. However, this opinion 0 bug makes things stale and boring in future turns. As countries would stop sending you insults, countries won't go to war with you (unless your ally nation goes to war with them or there are only a handful of Civs left which forces AI to make 0 opinion countries go to war against each other), you cannot have 'free military access request' because the opinion cant be changed. The best way is to do a "trade request" where you offer the country amount that is a significant percentage of their economy like 20 or 30 percent and then only they will let you go through their territories.


I STILL WON'T RECOMMEND PLAYING THIS GAME BUT I PLAY IT BECAUSE I LOVE THE PROGRESS I HAVE MADE SO FAR AND THERE IS MORE TO LEARN FOR ME FROM THIS. BUT FOR THE ONES WHO DO NOT LIKE SLOW  "DEGENERATIVE" GAMEPLAY IN THESE STRATEGIC GAMES WON'T GET ANY THRILL OUT OF IT.


================ OLD REVIEW BELOW ==================

If I had known that the developer of this game has stopped working on making bug fixes to this game, I would've never bought this game. I find these kinds of game very entertaining and I love them but this game could use a lot of bug fixing and changes (like addition of multiplayer). The developer did "promise" on making bug fixes in 2019 but after that he left the game completely. The game has several core bugs. The very bugs that ruin your game experience. I will list some of the major bugs in a below list. I may not list some of the bugs that I haven't yet discovered because it has only been 100 hours.
BUGS:-
1. Opinion (in diplomacy) between countries sometimes falls down to 0 and sticks to it. You cannot do anything to change The only fix is to start a new game and you will lose all of your progress but it is recommended that you go with a new run as there won't be much action after this bug comes up. It has become very frequent for me lately in the game. THERE IS NO FIX UNLESS THE DEVELOPER MAKES THE CODE OPEN SOURCE OR MAKES THE CHANGES HIMSELF.

2. ECONOMY BUG: This bug is very annoying especially if you get a large country such as India or China. I once got India and even before I could start doing something major after 5000th run I noticed my economy was going up like other countries. I noticed 90% of my provinces were down to 99 economy and I couldn't even raise them by investing in them. I found the fix which was to abandon them and then recolonise them. I was successful in doing so but not at the expense of losing my rank from 1 to 30 in just a few turns because I would also get slapped with a lot of wars.

3. Saved games. I once saved a game but I lost it. I don't have much details because it only happened to me once. It also could be my negligence but I have read several forums in this game which have had save games problem a lot.

4. City name changes and civilisation name changes revert back after loading saved game. This is a consistent issue. After you make changes to a city or civilisations name, the settings revert back to the original names after loading the saved game. This is a very in-your-face issue and the developer never made an effort to improve these bugs.

5. TRADE REQUEST BUGS:-  Buying of Provinces is impossible. I tried this several times when I was in low income economy civilisations. But now in one of the current runs of the game I am at an economy of 119 million Economy and I have around 200 million gold (yes I am at inflation and know how to deal with it). I tried trading for a province which was at 99 economy from an allied country with which i have 100+ diplomacy points and tried giving them all of my 200 million money but they still refused. So far none of the countries let lose their provinces even on trading 200 million golds. Weird, It's a useless feature then. No country likes to give back Gold if you offer them your province. They will take provinces with no money to offer which is weird even when you try to deal with high income economies that can give money for your provinces.

6. I am not sure if this is a bug or not but in one of my runs as India I had allied with Pakistan, China, Bangladesh and Malaysia. Malaysia went to war against its own allies and did not even split from the Alliance which is weird. After the 100% defeat of Malaysia, for some reason all countries could not occupy Malaysia and it was left for good and was still part of the alliance. Weird. 1000 runs after the war, Malaysia split itself into three "Malaysias", all of them had same names but three different colours. I noticed that this also happened with one of my vassals (Afghanistan) and both countries were at war with each other as well. I know this sounds far fetched but this literally happened.

After about 125 hours of playing AOH2, I can honestly say it's a good game. Even though it's not updated much and has a few rough edges, I still have fun playing it. The game is basically boiled down to improving your provinces and using a risk type combat system to fight wars. So now with that summary of the game out of the way, I'll show you a quick list of the pros and cons about the game.

Pros-
-Simple when you understand what you're doing.
-Has a large variety of bookmarks (Not only has stuff like modern day and WW2, but also has stuff like the American Civil War and the Great Emu war)
-Has a custom country and bookmark creator.
-Has a few mods that can be found on the AOH forms.
-Has 2 ways to progress through turns. (Has a next turn button and a timer like paradox's grand strategy games)
Cons-
-Can have some glitches.
-Has a "paradox" tutorial.
-Can get boring for some people.
-Has a couple exploits that make the game a little less difficult.
-Not as in depth as paradox's grand strategy games. (Paradox focuses on one time period, while this one is all throughout history)

So is it worth $5? To me, yes. Some other people just think it's bad because of bugs and the dev "Abandoning" the game. (He barely updates, but he did release the Asia map a while back) I kind of ignore the few bugs I run into and got a mod called "addon+" to add a few more civilizations and bookmarks. This game has been fun for me for 100+ hours, and I hope it's as fun to you.

I first got Age of History II when it was called  "Age of Civilizations II". Since then I've played about 180 hours, and I don't regret any of it. I bought this game thinking it was a ghetto HOI4. I soon learned that AOH2 is a unique, albeit simplish, map game with it's own personality and community. The game has all the expected map game features: Spectator mode, Nation builder(with a built-in custom flag designer), minority oppression mechanics and oodles of map based fun for you and your family. Do you want to see what would happen if Poland-Lithuania partitioned Austria, Prussia and Russia? Well you can! Do you wanna give a big "Fuck you" to the wehraboos who say "What if germany won ww2?" and "omg germany could have totally won ww2"? Well then just make a "What if Poland won WW2" scenario. All your Poland-based wet dreams can come true in this amazing(and affordable) budget map game!

So this is my first time playing a strategy other than Civilization (Sid meiers) and HoI4 and honestly this game is pretty good. Now time for me to go into detail.

Bugs: There are a couple but they are hard to get, for example if you try to commit peace twice the peace offer will sometimes cancel itself entirely having to make it over again but that's no big deal, the bigger problem which is very hard to find is when you annex a vassal and their units stay behind the only three countries that like to do this are: Macedonia,Laos,Khmer Union. And really these are all the bugs I could find

Opinions: So I have a few critical opinions of my I'd like to share, first off their is no Cold war,Great War, which is a big part of modern history. Now my second opinion is that you can form a country without certain requirements other than land like for example you can have a Horde Soviet Union or a Communist Austria Hungary, and now I know this is your own fate but still I feel like to form a country you should at least change your ideology to the country's last ideology instead of being something weird that doesn't make sense like a Horde Soviet Union. Third Opinion this game needs more formables, I had to make most of my for example to form Persian empire I made Iran have to form a much more expanded Qajar (at its peak) to form it or a Republic of china for Taiwan to invade China.

Overall Score of the game: 8/10 (Simple and historically accurate with barely any bugs that are easy to find)

--A few downsides are once you have a leader they don't change, even if it's been a really long time, and the battle is strategic, but there are not tanks, planes, ships, etc, and you can only make infantry, or armies.

Fun game, control any civilization, at almost any time in history, fun. Though it could use some game play improvements.

First, there needs to be a few more things to monitor, only needing to focus on money gets boring, and I know there's happiness, but that's too easy to keep at 100%, there should be things such as food, natural resources, etc, and you could make it so each region has a resource in them, and you could even base it on actual real world resources, like oil in the Venezuela, or iron in Sweden, and the game wouldn't even have to change much, less food=lower happiness, less resources=less trade, simple.

Second, please, PLEASE update the AI system, you cant coordinate attacks at all,the AI just throws troops at the enemy basically, trading provinces is impossible, even with me giving more than getting, the AI never changes government type, so if it's a horde, its going to stay that way, no matter the size, wealth, etc, they are so slow to build their economy and troops, often times, they will want peace, the terms are fair, I agree with them, and then they just, REFUSE?? So now they are spamming peace terms, and they will still refuse, every time, 300 turns later, still refusing, and you cant choose to just, not look at the terms, so every. god. damn. turn. you gotta look at these stupid peace terms, accept, only to get rejected once again, and keep in mind, you can go through 3000 turns in a few HOURS, so it gets really annoying.

Third, more maps please, preferably WW1 or the Russian Civil War, it gets boring after a while with so many similar maps.

Fourth, different kinds of troops, and it could be based on era, if you move into a different era, new kinds of troops, like chariots during the Romans, or tanks during WW2, because it kind of makes you feel like you're fighting with spears and swords in modern day, when its the exact same combat game play during the ancient Greeks.

Finally, please make an option to turn off leaders names and pictures, I really enjoy playing Germany in WW2, but don't want to be associated with Hitler, a crazy mass murderer, or Stalin, the cruel dictator, or people who I have never even heard of, this game is meant to make you feel like you're in control, so having the actual president of the USA staring back at you kind of defeats the point.

Not simple to learn, frustrating to learn. The tutorial is short and only covers a bare minimum (UI buttons, taking turns, basic mechanics). Want to know what a change of government does? Nope, just have to try it and see if you can guess what changed. The diplomacy is a mess. You go to war and win, then you have to negotiate, but there is no support explaining how this works. AI can force surrender in a turn, but it isn't even an option in negotiations. Dev needs to explain how this game works. It like playing Risk without the rule book and the AI has different rules.

good game

I've done it. I've put in over 250 hours into a 5$ phone app game brought over to PC. I did a review 2 years ago, but i think its time to do another. 

This game is amazing. "yeah yeah how amazing can a 5$ game be?" well it's great. It satisfies the weird urge we humans have to see a map painted our color. The replayability is huge, i'd argue you find just as much replay value in this game as, Minecraft or Terraria. It's like a paradox game, but actually fun and gets straight to the point. One of the few games where you can go from a 1 province nation, to a glorious Empire in no time. The graphics leave a little to be desired, but thankfully theres few mods out there that change the map up and of course, add many more scenarios. That's another thing. The mods make this game epic. my first 200 hours was without mods. 

However, i been praising this game a lot, but lets get to the flaws. The man who made this game, hardly updates. couple times a year if we're lucky. He also added no DLC, which, this game came out in 2018, and it's [CURRENT YEAR] so you'd think we would've gotten some DLC that add in more scenarios. Yes there are free mods you can install, but most people won't install those mods, for whatever reason, so they may only play a dozen or so hours and never play again. Wish the maker of this game would give us updates, or least be honest with us on if he's given up or not on this game. Also the editor for this game, is difficult, so don't think you can rush in and make a custom civ, with (custom) flag and leader in seconds, cause you won't. 

All in all, its a cheap, fun, addictive game that i strongly encourage everyone to buy, if you're a fan of map painter like games. For the price of one cheeseburger, you can get hundreds if not thousands of hours of play-time.

I enjoy this game greatly. I would compare it to a game like eu4 except it is turn based and much more simple (very cheap too) while still boasting many features. The ability to easily customise scenarios, civilisations and many more is great, this is probably my favourite thing to do and making historical and alt history maps are fun to try out. 
I will say though there are a few bugs in this game, I haven't found too many and I usually play this on a shitty school laptop. The ai in this is not that smart and can often annoy you and mess up your games (although if you play it smart you should be fine). The final thing I would add is the developer of the game seemed to of have abandoned the game for a really long time then has made a return with a new asia map very recently so if you do purchase it do not expect consistent updates.

This game is pretty quick to learn and good for killing time. The scenario editor is by far the best part of the game and the best scenario editor I've ever seen. It really makes me wonder why other games (*cough* HoI) haven't implemented an in-game scenario editor. 

But there are cons to the game too:
-Purchasing provinces simply doesn't work
-There's no easy way to share the scenarios you've created, as the creator never bothered to create a Steam workshop for this game, despite promising to do so
-Uncolonized provinces can be claimed by a tribal civilization, making them unable to be colonized

Where can i start? AoH is a cheap but yet enjoyable game, you can play as any nation in a time span from 5 AC to 5000 AC, that is 4995 years.
The graphics are decent considering it is a map game, but personally in a map game you shouldn't even mind about graphics.
The HUD is pretty understandable and even without the tutorial you will still understand the game.
Let's talk about the good things:
Economy: This game has a pretty simple but nice economy, there is nothing better than turning your nation in a super power by just investing in provinces, it is pretty rewarding and it doesn't force you to conquer land to become the strongest nation in the world.
Nations: You can play has a lot of nations, want to play as the roman empire? AoH has got you covered. Want to play as that turkmenistan nation in the 1400? Fell free to do so.
Editor: The editor is what makes the game special, you can make: events,nations,scenarios,disease (through modding but modding is really easy),ideologies (modding again but it is extremely easy),leaders.
Meh things:
Vassals aren't that useful: Vassals can declare war, they act like an indipendent nation by exception that they will most of the time accept your request to join wars and they will give money, but other than that they are pretty useless.
Diplomacy: Diplomacy is actually pretty good but some things are broken and/or unexplained (cough cough unions cough cough), you will never be able to buy a province even if you offer them thousands of gold and it is pretty broken.
Exploits: Exploits everywhere! Maybe i should unite this with the diplomacy section but i wanted to divide it. This game is extremely bugged, you can literally request an ally to invade his friend (even if it is stronger) and he will! This brokens the game in the worse way possible: you got invaded? just ask 300 nations to help you in the war.
Bad things:
The combat: THE COMBAT, THE FUCKING COMBAT. In a game where conquering is a big part of thingies you can't make combat so bland. There is only one unit type: infantry, that's it.
Combat is extremely boring and frustrating, as you can divide your 100 army in armies of 10 and you will be able to conquer 10  provinces, have a good time trying to catch those bastards!
Combat also brokes any logistic and logical law: a small nation that invades russia through siberia with a 11k army and then just stands there. No logistic problems, nothing! This is extremely frustrating.
In conclusion:
The game is very enjoyable,even with the broken diplomacy you can do a lot of things and you will spend hours trying to turn a country in the strongest country ever, i recommend it because of its editor and other thingies.
really fun games , love creating my own scenarios but game really needs multiplayer and further updates to reach it's true potential
